posts.com: Why was the Iron Age hillfort Cadbury in Britains southwest Somerset region reoccupied in the late 5th or early 6th century?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It situated on the edge of the Somerset levels 8km north-east of Yeovil.
In the Middle Ages this region was enclosed and drained, but at the time of the late 5th/early 6th century it would have all still been waterways - locations that are hills today like the Glastonbury Tor would have been islands.
And the Tor is visible from the summit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56932701
Too much crime in Cheddar so people moved

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This region was still under Romano-Briton control, the Saxons would not expand until the 600s.
Large quantities of Mediterranean pottery and glassware were uncovered in the excavation, to have afforded importing it and transporting so far in land would suggest a very powerful group or individual.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56932781

Who could command such resources and manpower.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Even today in a reduced state it still commands the region.
An important point about the name Cadbury is this is Saxon and so not what it would have been called.
You can always identify the origin of these names ending in -bury, or -burgh like Edinburgh, as Saxon forts or fortified town. The German -burg has the same origin. As they did not control the region until the 600s it must have been renamed Cadbury some time after.

>>56921842
It takes very large detectors as neutrinos are only weakly interacting, but not that much computing power. For example the Data taking in Borexino (>>56921857) was done on a single PC bought in 2006...

>>56922176
It works in principle if you have enough statistics. The energy profile of various Uranium or Polonium decay chains would give you distinct energy spectra of the (anti-)neutrinos. Typically this is proposed for non-proliferation, as you can put a reasonably sized detector very close to a nuclear power plant and monitor if they try to produce weapon grade plutonium and so on.

>>56927739
Real time neutrino detectors are made up either of water or liquid scintillator. In water the neutrino recoil electron prdouces Cherenkov radiation and in the liquid scintilllator the molecules produces fluoresence light.
These optical photons are then detected via PMTs.
The analysis is then typically performed on the energy spectrum, i.e. the number of detected photons for a large number of neutrino events.
The analysis is not so heavy on the computation, but if you want to produce a good Monte Carlo simulation model it can take a thousand CPU hours or so.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56928005
The Uranium decay chain produces anti-neutrinos, which are detected via the inverse beta-decay.
antineutrino + proton -> positron + neutron
The positron annihilates immediately with an electron sending out two gamma-rays and the neutron is then captured.
Here Gadolinum is used because it has the largest neutron section of all elements. For normal hydrogen the mean time for neutron capture is about 260 µs, for Gadolinium its only 17µs, I think.
The problem is that anti-neutrinos do not provide a directional information because of this detection process.
You cannot pin-point a anti-neutrino source like a submarine or a nuclear power plant. The best you can do is to measure an increase of anti-neutrino events above the background.

>>56929426
This balls are the light detectors of the KM3Net experiment in the mediterranean. It will be used for the search of ultra-high energy neutrinos from outside of our galaxy. As such it very sparsely instrumented and uses the sea water as a Cherenkov medium.
KM3Net cannot be used to detect anti-neutrinos, meaning it cannot sea nuclear submarines or power plants. A similar detector is the IceCube Neutrino Observatory at the south pole, using the ice as a Cherenkov medium.
America has no such detectors, as they have different priorities for their neutrino physics program (accelerators in the Fermilab).

>343mm is a bit over 13.5 inches, then you have to factor in the suppressor for actual use.

The thing you are missing is that the ballistics are way better, even out of the short barrel, which is what the main goal was.

Complain about volume of fire if you want to complain about something.

>They should get rid of the 240 and go with an old weapon that is still in 5.56mm and will suffer from the ballistics and lethality issues of of the 249 while being just as heavy as the 250, without a suppressor.

>Inb4 "you can chamber it in 7.62mm of 6.5 Mememoore"

Now you have two different types of ammo and the thing is heavier. I can understand concerns about the usefulness of the M5, but the M250? The only decent complaint is that the 250 isn't worth the switch to 6.8mm in the service rifle. How is a lighter MG with far better ballistics for the role worse?

240 is great but too fucking heavy. 250 fixes that main issue.

As to other posts about effective ranges, the idea here is that the optic makes the improved ballistics more relevant. I have not used it so I can't say if this is true. Certainly true fire control systems that only fire on calculated hits by the ballistics computer will deal with the capacity and recoil issue, but they aren't used widely yet. I can say that you certainly do see people at those distances. The idea that more range is useless because people haven't historically chosen to engage outside their weapons effective range is circular reasoning.

Optics matter a lot. WWI was fought with .30-06 out of 24 inch barrels, often in very open terrain thanks to years of shelling. But the effective range considered for the 1903 was lower than the M4. This is partly changing standards but maintainance, reliability, and optics matter a lot. Ballistics wise the 1903 BTFOs the M4, and it was used as a sniper to 1973.

Point with the 1903 being that obviously ballistics was not a limiting factor in effective range in the early to mid 20th century. Continued improvements in accuracy mean that ballistics is now a limiting factor.

IDK, I don't think the service rifle will much different if we're talking 2030-2050. The better LMG will be a boost. What will matter more is somehow getting designators or some other system for using rifle fire control systems to flag targets for squad level drones or the battlefield management system so artillery can be directed in by any rifleman. Bullet ballistics don't matter as much when you're getting to a point where IFVs or trailing ground drones can carry fully autonomous 60mm or 81mm mortars and sending them in is as easy as designating a spot with target recognition assistance. That's the fire power that matters. Maybe throw in a drone/small artillery support squad for every 3-4 fire teams so you have rapid spotting, mortar, and 105mm field gun backup on demand, organic. When the gun can aim itself based on a drone feed and fire itself and all the human has to do is fix issues and approve fire missions, you don't need a big team to run some serious fire power.

The LMG will still work better and since I think indirect fire will become more and more key, I like the switch. But yeah, 800 meters in 2035, you probably just click a button and pick related on some ground drone snaps off a mortar to fuck the target. No body armor is going to work for pressure waves from accurate mortar, grenade, arty fire lol.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56933185
Ethnic Romans weren't very good horseman, so poorly.
But they had many skilled auxiliary cavalry units from Gaul to North Africa who were very effective light cavalry. I believe European cavalry of the Roman Empire often fought primarily with javelins, but North African and Middle-Eastern cavalry of the Empire would use many kinds of weapons.
But even with auxiliaries Rome before the division of the empire didn't really use heavy cavalry.

Alexander the Great's Companion cavalry were well before Rome and had similar technology but were definitely heavy cavalry. They used saddles, a 2-handed lance and were famously effective even without stirrups.

Ancient Iranians had possibly the first heavy cavalry something like 800BC which is extremely early and so accurate info is scarce. They absolutely had armoured soldiers that rode horses, and while it is possible they dismounted to fight it's more possible they fought on horseback, because they're depicted with 2 handed lances. They also had no stirrups but they didn't even have proper saddles. Yet they were still charging into someone.

Ancient cavalry, stirrups, saddles, all this stuff is a constantly changing historical field but the modern view seems to be that the most important cavalry technology is Big Horses.
The Classical Romans didn't use heavy cavalry even with auxiliaries and Europe at the time had small horses.
The Classical Greeks didn't use heavy cavalry until Phillip II and the Macedonians turned up with bigger west asian horses.
Ancient Iranians probably got bigger horses from central asian pastoralists, but Iranians had the technology and wealth to make armour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56935818
>Why 1 tank for 4 million $ is better than 4 tank for 1 million $ each?
Modern professional armies don't tend to have the numbers the older conscript armies did. They are limited by the number of men they can recruit from the civilian population but in return they have a much higher quality of soldier. So think of a modern army like a box and you can only fit so much equipment in it, you may be able to afford 1000 tanks but you can only realistically man 500 of them. So with a strong western economy backing you and a thought process focused on increasing your armies capabilities it becomes the smart move to pay the 4 million for that slight advantage.

In a total war scenario where mobilization and conscription occur this calculation may change as you begin to focus on equipping a much larger force. You might see expensive tanks, IFV's, planes and helicopters supplemented by cheaper, lighter, quicker to produce vehicles in an effort to equip the largest number of men possible, especially from civilian industry converted for war use. In the case of a standing peace time army though, you want to give those men the best.

As for your picture OP, the AMX-10RC was never supposed to replace the Leclerc, it existed because it had a role that it could not fulfill, specifically it's pairing of firepower with very high mobility.

>>56933812
this is a good take, but also it's important to note that IMO what makes the most difference in an example where tanks are on relatively equal terms is the crew itself.
A crew that has lots of training together, can predict each others movements and commands, tight nit, experts in their field, etc is going to destroy a crew that is just a bunch of random retards shoved into a tank even if they know their job but don't know each other.
The same goes for aircraft, a shitty pilot in the best plane will get shot down by the best pilot in a shitty plane.
I was an Abrams crewman, and it is a great tank, the thermals on it are amazing, the coax is like a sniper rifle, highly effective round, CITV was a game changer, etc
Maintenance on it sucked, it always seemed to be breaking down even though we did preventative maintenance constantly.
The Russian tanks are good too though. The thing that worried me the most about the T72 style of tanks is how small the turret is and low of a profile. Very hard to hit one if the opposing command knows how to properly use defilade. However seeing videos of Russian tanks in Ukraine it looks like they're all retarded. It goes everything against what I know about moving around in a tank to see these tanks driving around alone. No other tanks, no infantry screens, no IFVs, just one tank rolling around like they're in the hood or something. Ukrainians do it too though so gonna be interesting to see Abrams getting merced because of how retarded their crews are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56913747
>I was always wondering why destroyed tanks always looks so rusty. Is this what the metal/paint looks like after being exposed to fire?
From a chemical perspective, a fire is really nothing more than rust happening >extremely< quickly. The "ash" from burning it is straight-up particulate metal oxides. So once a vee catches fire, anything that burnt is going to be massively rusted. The areas around the edges of the burn that lost their heat treat and/or carbon and other alloys are going to be extremely vulnerable to further rusting, and fires almost always blister or burn off the anti-corrosion paint on otherwise untouched areas. Given a few weeks of exposure they're also gonna rust to fuck.

I meant Centurion. Merkava 1 had a engine, tracks and transmission based on the Centurion and all further Merkava developments are based on that just like the Pokpung-Ho is based on a T-62. Merkavas actually have a older tech base than the current DPRK tank designs.

As a base to develop new designs the T-62 is actually the best Soviet design, it doesn't have the autoloader, has a huge turret ring that can handle a much bigger gun than designed for and the hull has a (relatively) large amount of space if you use western style turret bustle ammo storage like the DPRK does.

The T-62 base can be upgraded, the T-72 cannot due to the combination of ammo storage and autoloader being intrinsic to the basic design.

Pic related, you can do really weird and crazy shit with the base T-62 hull let alone when you make it 6-7 feet longer and add 2 extra road wheels.

>>56929541
The Y-axis is percentage of area covered, X-axis is level of protection in mm RHA equivalent. The left column is against kinetic penetrators and the right column is against shaped charges, both at a 20 degree angle. So for example, 50% of the exposed parts of the M1A2 turret has protection equivalent to 600 mm RHA or more from a kinetic penetrator fired from a 20 degree angle. The pictures show in green which parts of the turrets have a protection level of 700 and 1200 mm RHA or more for kinetic penetrators and shaped charges respectively.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56929541
Its a bit of a retarded graph, but the X axis is the mm RHA protection, and the Y axis is the percentage of the area of the turret corresponding to at least that level of protection from a 20* angle. The left column is vs a 700mm penetrating KE round (APFSDS), the right column is vs a 1200mm penetrating chemical round (HEAT).

So for the M1A2, from a 20 degree bearing angle of impact, 80% of the turret face is protected to at least 400mm RHA, 60% 500mm, 20% 700mm, and 18% 800mm.
For the Leo2A5, 85% is protected to at least 400mm, 78% is protected to at least 600mm, and 78% is protected to at least 800mm.
The image shows the area of the turret which protects vs the max (800 ke or 1600 ce) amount in green, the required amount in orange (700ke or 1200 ce), and any less than that in red.

So this shows that the M1A2 cheeks offer roughly 4-600mm KE protection on average, with large area weakspots being the turret sides, roof, and lower turret. It also shows that M1A2 cheeks offer 500-900/950mm vs CE on average. Given that the chobham armoured Challenger mk.1 (which has a reasonably similar turret face) had roughly 435-500mm on its turret cheeks from a 20* impact bearing vs DM23, and around 700mm vs CE. It means that 2nd gen DU offers an increase in protection of about ~65-165 mm over Chobham armour vs KE, and ~200/250mm vs CE. While the leopard, without DU composite of any sort, has a majority coverage of 800mm vs KE. and 1600mm vs CE. Albeit the leo has a different turret design, with the wedge increasing the LOS thickness of the armour.
Therefore DU, or at least 2nd gen DU, isnt actually very good, being only slightly better than the original chobham armour. Much better protection can easily be afforded without its inclusion. I'd expect 3rd gen to be an improvement enough to somewhat match a 2a5, but i'd equally expect a Leo2a6 or 7 to still be ahead in terms of armour. That being said, the M1A2 ought to win in hull armour over a Leo2A5.

>>56935617
A combination of several factors:

>Inferior optics
See less stuff, especially modern threats with IR masking.

>inferior armor
Die to more threats with higher likelyhood

>inferior mobility
A tank derives a lot of its individual combat value by being able to move protected firepower around the battlefield quickly. Ceteribus paribus a slower tank is always worse because it will get outmaneuvered.

>inferior lethality
Being able to destroy less things at lower range sucks. Not being able to reliably engage moving targets or on the move is bad.

>no BMS integration
The absolute nightmare.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56917722
you need to get rid of redundancies. the axe and e-tool is one you already identified. cold weather gear and wet weather gear should be able to layer with each other. spare underwear usually goes uneeded and spare socks can be kept to a minimum with wool ones. spare pants can be a part of cold/wet gear.

sleep system can be very light if you don't care about hiding and use ultralight backpacking gear. food/water can just be a jar of peanut butter, electrolyte packets, and a sawyer filter to sustain water source. fire kit should be reliable and not for comfy camping with the in-laws. a bic disposable kept close to base layers or skin will function in all conditions barring extreme cold the mini blowtorches will also be hotter and work in the wind. tinder can be the cheap firestarters found in every outdoors section. is the ammo for people or animals? people, a spare mag. animals, you need a way to process meat and there was no knife listed in the kit.

if you don't do anything retarded, this will buy you at least a weeks time

>>56909545
To anyone still reading this thread, how do you break a maul? Jesus. Ok here is what to do, get any old truck tire with a 16 inch center. Put it where you can walk around it at a arm and maul length 360 degrees. Put wood upright in middle, end grain up. Split aiming withing 2 inches of the edge. Rotate around the tire. Do not reach over split wood to what's behind it - rotate! You will split wood fast. You will not break handles. As wood is split, remove and replace so tire is 60 to 80% full. t. Eagle Scout, woodworker, tool junkie. I split with a 50 year old Stanley maul w/ the original hickory handle that was my dads. About a chord and a half a year. It helps to put a thin slab or plywood at the bottom

>>56931613
I think it wasn't necessarily that we didn't have a reason, but more that we didn't have the tech developed yet to make it worthwhile, or at least not on a mass, cost effective scale.
The displays were shit.
Noise cancelling mikes were either enormous, fragile, or inadequate.
Batteries didn't have the necessary duration at an acceptable weight.
Connectivity wasn't reliable enough nor day enough.

I think the latest tech they're working on uses a tiny individual mounted generator fueled by windshield washer fluid to power everything should batteries not suffice.
I believe it's a solid state proton exchange membrane power cell, so reliable, durable, fueled cheaply, and won't explode if it takes shrapnel or a hard knock in the wrong spot.
Pretty neat stuff.

posts.com:
>Among other weapons, I had an extraordinary rifle that carried a half-pound percussion shell—this instrument of torture to the hunter was not sufficiently heavy for the weight of the projectile; it only weighed twenty pounds: thus, with a charge of ten drachms [270 grains] of powder, behind a half-pound shell, the recoil was so terrific, that I spun around like a weathercock in a hurricane. I really dreaded my own rifle, although I had been accustomed to heavy charges of powder, and severe recoil for some years. None of my men could fire it, and it was looked upon with a species of awe, and it was named "Jenna-El-Mootfah" (Child of a Cannon) by the Arabs, which being far too long a name for practice, I christened it the "Baby;" and the scream of this "Baby" loaded with a half-pound shell was always fatal. It was far too severe, and I very seldom fired it, but it is a curious fact, that I never fired a shot with that rifle without bagging: the entire practice, during several years, was confined to about twenty shots. I was afraid to use it; but now and then it was absolutely necessary that it should be cleaned, after months of staying loaded. On such occasions my men had the gratification of firing it, and the explosion was always accompanied by two men falling on their backs (one having propped up the shooter), and the "Baby" flying some yards behind them. This rifle was made by Holland & Holland, of Bond Street, and I could highly recommend it for the Goliath of Gath, but not for the men of A.D. 1866.
>—Sir Samuel White Baker, The Albert N'Yanza, Great Basin Of The Nile

>>56905118
Yeah, that's one of them. I recognize the range.

I think that old rifle would actually be worse to fire compared to what those arabs were shooting. If memory serves the arab guys were shooting things like .577 T-Rex, .577 Nitro Express, .505 Gibbs, etc. Let's use those and throw .600 NE in there as well.
From Chuck Hawk's website:
.470 Mbogo = 84 ft-lb recoil
.500 NE = 75 ft-lb
.577 NE = 127 ft-lb
.600 NE = 154 ft-lb
.577 T-Rex = 110 ft-lb
.505 Gibbs = 82 ft-lb

Now, head over to shooters's calculator and type in the numbers for this. 3500 grain bullet (1/2 lb), 270 grains of powder, 20 lb gun weight. We don't know the muzzle velocity exactly but I think 1000 fps is a safe estimate, that is well below the velocities reported by Cal Pappas for a 10-dram 4-bore rifle load firing a conical slug. That gives a whopping 373 ft-lb, even worse than firing both barrels of a .600 NE at the same time.

>>56905672
Most combination gun-and-melee-weapons came from the time when gun technology sucked, so once you fired your one shot (assuming it even went off) you suddenly had a useless piece of metal in your hands, so having the gun incorporated into a mace, halberd, axe, etc, made some sense when it wasn't practical to reload.
The Day's truncheon came out at a time when firearm technology wasn't so shitty, as far as I've read they were reliable. The problem of course was that a truncheon was supposed to be a less lethal sort of weapon and a solid brass bird's head would absolutely cave in a skull without much effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56906690
That was from a time before NE's existed. In the days of black powder the way to make the gun more powerful was to make the bore ever larger. They also played around with explosive bullets. Note that he mentions a "percussion shell" and then proceeds to talk about how they have to fire the gun every so often if it had been sitting loaded for too long...that's also a clue. If it had been loaded with an ordinary lead bullet they could have pulled it out the muzzle using a screw on the end of the ramrod. But in this case the gun was loaded with a bullet packed with explosive and a primer in the nose so they couldn't pull it out that way.

Anyway, he wrote about that gun in 1866, the first NE cartridge, the .450, didn't exist until 1898. And yeah, once those hit the market the big "bore" gauge rifles quickly fell out of use.

>>56902658
Original Pauley brass cartridge cases.
Napoleonic era, predated the percussion cap.
Ignition worked by using a spring punger that drove compressed air into the priming compound. This compressed air got extremely hot, enough to light the compound, ignite the main powder charge, and discharge the cartridge.
Similar in concept to a fire piston, like people bring camping.

>>56922919
>but why? wouldn't putting them in rectangular boxes save up on space? or is that empty space used for something else?
One man can roll a barrel, you need 2-3 to safely handle a crate that size. When you're critically short on labor, and don't have forklifts, that can matter a lot. Big reason why they were still used in shipping until the invention of the modern ISO containers. Paying your cargo handlers has always been one of the biggest expenses of shipping stuff.
Second, barrels only take two machining operations to run off of a belt of sheet metal (cut, roll around a mandrel with the ribs and weld). Then you drop in the inserts, cap 'em off with round plates, and run 'em out to the back yard. A metal crate takes three folds, four welds, and a much more complex cut for the body, plus you need hinges. Wooden crates were cheaper but neither waterproof nor anywhere as tough, and wooden crates required a lot of labor you could automate with barrels.
Finally, the barrels handled being parachuted out of planes much better than the crates in Army tests -- they supplied partisans for several years by literally kicking barrels of guns out of the back of small transports in occupied territory. Did the same thing for resupplying paratroopers and sending down their heavy weapons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Previous >>56842716
Airsofting with FP LAM edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I know it’s in the poor anon guide, but I’ll post my quick review of the night fox.

>Pros

-Works great for night hiking.
You can see about 25 feet in front of you at all times, so it quite nice to walk around with.

-Pretty lightweight, went on a 2 hour hike wearing it, neck felt fine.

-The built in IR illuminator works excellently, but I still used a helmet mounted light to save battery.

-Worked in -30 Fahrenheit weather.

-Able to hit soda can sized targets from 50 feet away using a holographic sight. 100 feet with larger targets.

-Has in built zoom, but I’ve never found a use for it.

-Battery life when not using built in IR illuminators is forever.

>Cons

-The mount it comes with is pretty shit, literally just a go-pro headband thing. Doesn’t work at all.

-Range is only 25 feet, which is fine for just walking, but don’t expect to see across the field.

-1080p quality, can make it difficult to figure out what your seeing.

-When using built in illuminators, two large red circles are present.

>Mitigating Cons

-Buy a 30 dollar airsoft helmet off Amazon for a better mounting platform. Buy Go-Pro extended mount arms or 3D print them. And you’ll have a great fit. I would recommend a counterweight if you are using an Amazon helmet.

-For extended battery life and lesser detection, use a 15 dollar Amazon IR light and get a helmet light mount or 3D print one.

>Overall

I quite like my little night-fox, and since I got it on sale and 3D printed a good few parts, my total cost was 250 bucks for helmet and light. Used it to go hiking and plink at night.

If anyone’s interested I’ll post a WEBM of me hiking with it, or the nerf monocular setup.

>Can the true warrior spirit be trained or is it some kind of genetic sociopathy?
I don't think trained is the right word but developed for certain. Here are some things to consider:
1. A boy with an overly militaristic father, may live in an environment of emasculation until he moves out.
2. A boy who has not received enough rough and tumble play, will not understand the difference between what physical inputs should be interpreted as pain from injury and pain that is just communication. This will make him weak as something like lifting a heavy weight may "hurt".
3. A boy who is raised on daytime television without the philosophical input of masculinity will have to develop that independently later in life.

Contrariwise, a boy who recieved lots of rough and tumble play with a loving but masculine father figure, will inherently be better able to interpret physical and emotional pain and better able to stand up like a man.

So, I don't know of any training beyond confidence and competence improvement but I do believe you can develop it over time with the correct environmental inputs. That's just my 2 cents, I'm not a psychologist.

>>56933683
it's a little more recent but if you are interested in human domestication, look up the development of large-scale brachiocephalic populations among peasants in Eastern and Central Europe. Basically, around the time the introduction of the heavy plow, human populations in places where the heavy plow was common became much more brachiocephalic (round headed) and this is likely to have been related to the fact that because of the number of livestock that would have been neded to operate such a plow, greater cooperation was needed among the peasant population, and instead of a farmer farming his own land, a village became responsible for plowing its entire land together.
Around this time, feeding babies pap instead of breast milk also became much more common in the same populations, suggesting that the nature of female participation in the labor force changed substantially.

>>56933199
You underestimate the power of bureaucracy. While it would be completely ridiculous for top brass to sign off on shitty ERA, it becomes less ridiculous when you understand that information doesn't flow from reality to the decision-makers unimpeded. Especially in Russia, they may be deploying tanks with nonfunctional equipment but because the inspection has gone from the guys on the ground to a yes-man to a yes-man to a yes-man (ad nauseam) before reaching the people who actually might kinda-sorta give a shit that their ERA is actually cardboard, it's likely that the full reality never actually reaches the top brass.

It's a quirk of Russia's highly-centralized structures of authority and command that if you fill enough ranks with the people who will tell you what you want to hear or lose their jobs... you'll just end up hearing what you wanted to hear, regardless of what is the reality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Well now that all the obvious answers and pick it’s time for me to roll in with my sleeper hits
>Dai Senryaku VII
An excellent little war game were maps can be the size of the entirety of Australia yet you’re still expected to pick exactly how many magazines of ammunition your rifleman are carrying. I always boot up this game excited for some combined arms operations before remembering five hours into a match that this game is logistics simulator 2000 and America always wins not because it has better tanks or planes but because it has stratotankers and V-22s. The main campaign of this game takes place in the 2010s and has you playing as Germany against Israel for some reason.
>Total War Shogun 2
Considerably more realistic on a tactical level to nearly any other RTS in existence, shogun 2 is the best in the series but some of the others are pretty good too.
>Full Spectrum Warrior
A department of defense funded training program that was released commercially and is weirdly addictive. It’s based around squad level tactics, and was specifically intended to hammer in the principles of bounding fire. As a training program the game is extremely brutal. You have limited ammunition with the enemy has unlimited ammunition, the enemy has a chance of not getting hit if exposed to fire but your own soldiers are guaranteed to get hit if exposed to fire and you instantly lose if one of them dies. It’s pretty brutal but it taught me a lot of really valuable stuff that helped me IRL in officer training

Reliability issues, plus all-MIM small parts that you have to replace if you want good performance. By the time you do so, you're gonna be in it for Staccato money. Also, the BUL is a better stock gun than the Prodigy.

>why is MIM bad
MIM parts are harder and brittler than milled ones. This makes them very difficult to hand fit. Sear engagement, in particular, is hard to set with MIM parts. MIM parts are also more prone to breakage, especially for small, intricate parts like 1911 slide stops and ambi safety selectors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56929875
the grouping perspective is an interesting one, I think that does make quite a bit of sense. However, I also doubt novice shooters are really aiming exactly for critical spots like the heart or head. More like they are just dumping their mag at what they're trying to stop. It's also worth noting that once you get some training neither are really a problem to handle, and you should be doing this anyways. Either way, when you're shooting faster, you're not really going to get good shot placement. You realistically just need to be able to mitigate recoil enough to get enough shots on target, ideally the chest cavity to increase odds of hitting something vital. In this regard 5.7 does have the advantage as you can fit more in a magazine.

I think another metric worth comparing is projectile energy. 9mm has more energy, and the target's body must disperse that energy to stop the bullet. There are also more readily available options on the market like +P. That being said, it doesn't matter if the projectile has more energy if it doesn't hit anything important. The projectile not having enough energy to penetrate does matter, but the 5.7 doesn't try to expand nearly as much as 9mm.

For civilian use I don't really think there is enough of a difference personally for it to matter one way or another. Both are good and significantly better than nothing. I hope that with more 5.7 models on the market the price of the ammo will go down and we will see more use and get better data on effectiveness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56932963
No, I'm not, and you're being outwardly dishonest by claiming I am. Read my post again, particularly this:
>Again, MIM parts have their place in some applications.

MIM has its place, such as on applications where additional hardness doesn't matter. Locking blocks on Glocks, for instance, or firing pins on pretty much every striker-fired gun. Additionally, MIM has its place on parts where exact dimensionality doesn't matter, like on the grip safety of a 1911.

Having said that, MIM parts are absolutely not optimal on trigger assemblies, hence why ZERO high-end manufacturers of 1911s/2011s use them in such applications. They're a comparative bitch to hand-fit, and so any custom or semi-custom builder is not going to use them. MIM small parts on a 1911/2011 are invariably a cost saving maneuver. You can cope and seethe all you want on this point, but it doesn't make it less true.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56931147
This is more than a little misleading. The Soviets under Stalin in the late 1920's and very early 1930's started their automotive and tractor industries by basically scamming Henry Ford, but once it was off the ground, the Soviets were building their factories and designing their own things. The T-34 was being produced by mid-1940, and mass production was started by mid-1941 in four factories. More than 3000 were built by the end of 1941, before Lend Lease had gotten much off the ground, and 115 had been produced in 1940 as early production and evaluation models, all before the Soviet Union ever received any lend lease. And that's not even getting into Soviet pre-war tank production, the USSR had far more tanks than the US or UK, it had more tanks than Germany in 1941. The US struggled more with tank production than the USSR in the early war period.

>>56931361
Fug I'd just remove all the plastic (eg grips) and go to town with PB Blaster, some blue "shop" paper towels (go to Walmart, these things are absurdly priced), toothpicks, q-tips, a pack of cheap toothbrushes, etc. Can't be that thick. My SKS had a fuckload of grease in the barrel; doubt yours will be that greasy so just get a rag or shop towels and get to it. Basically any of them other than isopropyl (useful but not here) will help remove the dirt and "re-wet" the old grease. Is it rock hard or something?

Also, brake cleaner, I'd only use on steel guns, and blued steel guns only. Nothing with paint or a coating. Not on plastic. You really need to oil the fuck out of it afterwards, though; non-chlorinated brake cleaner is straight acetone in a can. And my god is that shit so much stronger (at least feeling) than acetone sold for removing nail polish. Forget to oil it afterwards and you will have a gun that looks like it came out of a sauna, coated in rust.

In fairness, the variation between peoples as to what a wendigo was, looked like, and could do, was significant.

Combine it with the traditional European view as demons as horned creatures then tell them about a wendigo and it follows that they'd picture the cannibalistic evil supernatural forest creature as something with horns or antlers. That last part was just my own speculation, though.

While there may be some similarities in the Horned god/Cernunnos and the cultural depictions of Wendigo’s, there is at least a gap of about 10,000-15,000 years when the Hunter gatherers who settled the Americas were still situated on the Eurasian mega continent.

One thing that apparently was a harbinger of becoming a Wendigo was having a dream; a dream where you are in the forest and given a meal of game meat & noticing that the game meat is human flesh, if you do not stop yourself from eating the human flesh in the dream you are doomed to turn into a Wendigo.

There were also two types of cannibalism at least among Algonquin tribes, there was a heroic cannibalism that came from eating the hearts of your enemies who you killed or captured in battle, this form of anthropophagy was common in several Native American tribes, my own Mohawk ancestors partook in these activities. The type that was shunned was when people out of desperation would eat their loved ones.

If you watch those videos I linked they go into detailed accounts of people being suspected of becoming wengidos and usually killed as a result. The suspicions were not unfounded, in one instance a woman showed up at a fur trading post and appeared famished, she feigned eating the food they gave to her & eventually there was a human shoulder blade found on the trail that she had taken to the post, she was given over to the locals and enthusiastically embraced their children which was unsettling. The natives watched her closely and in the middle of the njfht she got up to approach a child so one of the braves attempted to kill her with a tomahawk, almost losing that fight with her until he was helped by others in the group. That is one instance or many.


I am actually very interested in different lore and mythos and the commonality among cultures that exist throughout the world.

posts.com:
Ok, I did the gay math, and results I got suggest that reconnaissance aircraft that greatly aid Ukraine in their struggle against the forces of Mordor are, as I suspected, only useful in western and southern parts of Ukraine.


Boeing RC-135 I keep seeing flying over Poland near the Ukrainian border practically every day on Flightradar since 24 of February:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_RC-135

Altitude according to flightradar: 8.8km
https://www.flightradar24.com/49.12,28.62/6

Earth curvature calculator:
https://earthcurvature.com/

So, according to my gay math, at this altitude, the objects further than 335 kilometers from the airplane will be beyond the horison, thus physically impossible to detect by the airplane.
The internets say:
>The range and service ceiling are 5,550km and 15,200m (50,000ft) respectively.
Ok, so lets make that 440km to horizon.


I also kept seeing Global Hawk flying over the Black Sea to Crimea and back.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northrop_Grumman_RQ-4_Global_Hawk
It says here on wiki that it can climb up to 17km which gives us 470 kilometers to horizon at this altitude.

So I did this gay map which shows +/- maximal physical range of detection of ground units, beyond that range, ork ground forces can only be detected via satellite surveillance.

The "map" doesn't take into account different ground levels off course.

>The Russians have one great advantage: numbers. They can literally afford to send in surplus T-64's and T-72's in the hope that attrition will whittle down the numbers of the vastly superior Leopards, Challengers and Abrams.
They really can't. The thing about soviet union was that it actually had massive factories that were manufacturing new tanks, replacing destroyed stuff with the same or more modern equivalents.
Russia has scrapyards filled with badly maintained husks of ancient garbage and a single low-output factory.
And most of these husks will take lots of time and effort to be made operational again. Why do you think they are refitting t-62s when they still have parking lots of t-72s? Because before the war they already planned to sell the 62s to some shithole so they were at least able to start the engines.
To put it in simplest terms possible, they have no ability to replenish their loses faster than they take them.
And it will only get worse with time, seeing as pulling tanks out of the boneyards will obviously prioritise the ones in best condition and easiest to repair to be reactivated first - which means it will only get harder to get anything operational as time passes.

>>56932911
They can produce about 100-180 T-90s a year.
They can refurbish+upgrade about 50 T-80BVMs per year (out of 3000 in storage).
And they can overhaul+upgrade about 40 T-72B3Ms per month, although one year they managed 600 but that was before the invasion, but the cost of doing so is very high, almost that of just building a T-90. There is definitely a financial element to it as well as a logistical one.
Theres maybe 8-10,000 T-72s in storage and they wont last forever, there were originally some 15,000 and i think theyve scrapped most of the worst condition ones already.
Theres also several thousand T-64s and about 1,000 T-62s which they refurbed to try and sell before the invasion.

All told they can probably get about 630 reasonably modern tanks into service every year, and could maybe pull in 2000 obsolete ones.

Their operational fleet is (or was) about 2,600. If theyre actually unironically losing 1600 tanks a year then they cant keep it up for more than 2 or 3 years before their operational fleet is depleted beyond their ability to pull from storage or produce. They could still get a smaller tank fleet of around 630 back in yearly though, even with 100% losses, and could keep that up, theoretically, for about 16 years, if they find crew for them.

They can make engine and aircraft parts(ish). Thermals and microelectronics they struggle with, they've been bypassing import restrictions via shell companies in other countries e.g.french thermals. Big problem is most of their airframes are old or outdated, and they cant afford to buy more when their economy is the size of Italy's, except the government is even more corrupt, the army is massive, and they are trying to maintain no less than three different fleets. America has a lot of old airframes too, but the niggers are currently replacing most of their old planes with F-35s en-masse, while the Russians cannot.

SU-30 is from the mid 90s and is still being built, Russia has 130 (-8 now) and has another 28 on order but the rate of production isnt good at all now+theyre also trying to fill export orders.

SU-34: Originally a 90s design but most entered service in the 00s or 10s-146 in service (-11 now)

SU-35S is from 2010s: 110+18 on order (-1 now)

Mig29K: trying to order them to replace 22 SU-33s who reached their end of service date about 7 years ago

SU-57, their 5th gen fighter, 11 produced out of 76 total

Mig-35, 5th gen, 6 produced out of 24 (it has taken them 5 years)

These are all of the fighter planes that Russia has which were built in the last 20 years.
Mig-31 is old now and needs retiring, as does the Mig-29.
SU-24 design is over 50 years old+many airframes are from the cold war, despite modernisation, of 240 in inventory only 177 are flying (-9 now).
The SU-27, in service from 1985 but many manufactured in the 90s, still puts all of them above, or at, 30, and its showing. They had 359 flying in 2014, in 2021 they had only 101, not likely to last much longer.
In 10 years time, theyre unlikely to have >400 fighter/strike planes, including only 100 5th gen, respectable, but no more larping as a superpower.

The problem isn't always strictly a points one. Sometimes an ability is just objectively better than an older version of the same ability.

Case in point: Malignant Plaguecasters - a Death Guard HQ psyker (Death Guard being one of the early 9th edition) - have an ability called "Pestilential Fallout", whereby, the closest enemy unit within 12" suffers 1 mortal wound on a successful psychic test of 7+. Tyranid Maleceptors - Tyranids being one of the more recent books - have an identical ability, with the sole exception being that it deals 3 mortal wounds instead of 1. Now to be clear, Maleceptors are significantly more expensive and fulfill a different role, but the point remains that this is the level of design we're dealing with.

Not that GW cares to begin with, as their chief concern is obviously selling more models. The entire shitshow surrounding Leagues of Votann can attest to that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56927789
>The Age of the Imperium is not a technically inclined age, to have included descriptions of 'heads-up displays', 'computer links', etc, would have given the wrong impression entirely. This is an age where problems are solved by brute force and ignorance, where dangers are either too gross or too unthinkable to elicit any other response. The other reason why technical description has been avoided is that the Age of the Imperium lies more than forty thousand years in the future - at a stage in history when those headup displays and computers are about as innovative as stone circles.
>What scientific knowledge persists from the Dark Age of Technology is far above and beyond anything we can imagine from the perspective of the Twentieth Century. That understanding lies only with a select few - the Adeptus Mechanicus - the Tech-priests of the Imperium. Even their knowledge is somewhat debased, and the popular image of technology can be compared with that of witchcraft in medieval times.
>Those who come into contact with technology use it with reservations and a reverence that are almost religious. The Space Marines, for example, treat their equipment and armour as if if were imbued with a will of its own - a fine chest-plate, well looked after and constantly maintained may reward its wearer by saving his life; whereas a Marine who neglects his equipment may be struck down by a leaking suit or malfunctioning weapons. Such is the will of the Gods.

tl:dr the imperium is in an age where you use a hammer instead of a computer and trying to describe the imperium’s technology just leads to disappointment

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56929265

The Warhammer hobby is playing AND physically building your army. If you only care about playing, play on Table Top Simulator or play one of dozens other strategy games online.
You can get enough minis and hobby supplies to start assembling, converting, painting, designing bases, making terrain out of random trash, making army lists to collect towards, coming up with custom iconography for your army and generally get 90% of the excitement the hobby has to offer for like $200 or less. $200 more and you can easily play your first decently sized-battle, another $600 and you can play 2000 pts tournaments. You can't tell me $600 is a lot for a hobby on a fucking gun board.

And sure, you can also spend thousands upon thousands to have maximum fieldable amount of every unit in many different armies so you can always stay on top of the meta, but that's an exception, not the norm. Being a hyper-competitive player is a niche. So is collecting like 20,000 points of one army so you can play some freakishly huge battle or spending a fortune on high-end painting supplies to have nothing keeping you from producing the prettiest paint job the world has ever seen. This shit you see on the internet is an exception like Ronnie Coleman is to countless dudes who lift.

Checking to see if the bolt gap is in spec isn't a bad idea if you have a feeler gauge before you accept the transfer.
Otherwise just making sure there aren't any major cosmetic blemishes with the finish like dents or scratches, as well as making sure the ejector is properly riveted into place and isn't loose.
Definitely try and run some 124gr FMJ through it since they suggest at least a 500 round break in period.
I bought some extra extractor pins since those seem to be the cause of most of the issues people are having with them.
So far I haven't had a single issue with my AP5-P though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
NGAD is meant for one thing and one thing only
"Me touch you long range - lol call the cops"
It's a compliment to the B-21, and the networked drone fleet vehicles are cherry on top.

The F-35 is the workhorse, it's designed to replace an aging-out F-18 as the production goes up. The F-16 and F-15 are defunct and relegated to special-purpose and export, gap filling, etc.
I would expect a new F- plane to begin real development after the adaptive cycle engines are being finalized in trial, so ~late 2020s.

Keep in mind US plane development went like this:
>F-14: superiority - basically built solely for the AIM-54, a MiG-25 and Tupolev killer
>F-15: superiority - built to anally violate MiGs and Sukhois and never lose
>F-16: skirmish-striker and CAP - built to scout, clean up, and be a cheap small warfare target hitter
>F-18: carrier ops/CAP and "ordinance trucking" - built to replace the F-14 and be carrier friendly - and also shit out an assload of missiles to supplement/forward screen for carrier AAM
>F-22: stealth superiority - built to do two things: Shoot without being seen and track without being locked
>F-35: CAP/CAS/carrier - built to replace the F-15 via RCS reduction and BVR enhancement. Built to replace the F-16 via enhanced pilot information and missiles. Built to replace F-18 via sensorfusion/networking
>NGAD: long range BVR striker/bomber built to do superiority against Chinese navy and future Chinere Supal Dragoon Ultra Fighter Prane

A mess? Really depends on the politics cunts and economic situation. If the NGAD exists in a similar time-situation as the ATF program, maybe it will go the way of the F-22. China is really shitting itself to pieces and could crumble at any moment, not only that but Chinese technology is nowhere near what most people even choose to believe. 90% of their mil tech is still essentially 1980s Russian surplus, they can't get a 2010's gen fighter engine to work, and 90% of what you see is dressed up propaganda.

Armchair, OUT

What replaced both the F-14 and the Hornet was the Super Hornet, a jet introduced in the late 90s and although similar in name and design to the hornet, actually is about 30% bigger and features various modifications and improvements like rcs reduction, being the stealthiest non-5th gen plane to date.

You can search for Project farm, he tested some rust inhibitors and some of them build a wax film otherwise try WD40 specialist long term rust protection. That shit should form a pretty strong protection film after the solvent fleshed of.

Okay, yeah it's like I thought you are over committing. You don't need the Para lower, the Para bolt carrier, the extra spring or the extra guide rod. You see this picture? >>56927342
Site-Rite was complete ass, broke a year later and used some obscure chinese battery. The Gozier was actually really good and still works. If you have at least 20feet of space, lazers help you dial in your sights. Then you just have to dial up your elevation. I used the lasers a lot when I would get a new optic or firearm.

I don't need them as much now, because when I get a new optic, I just line it up with the old optic and I'm 90%-95% there. Lasers are just really good tools like dummy rounds. Lasers are even better if you don't have the ability to shoot once, check your target, shoot once, check your target. Many ranges won't allow you to walk up to your target when you want to check them. Another tactic I use, is that I'll take my high power scope, and I'll check my targets from the safety of the firing line.

>Guide rod is for the DSA rail cover I’ve got on my rifle right now
But that's Para spec... regular FAL guide rod and PARA guide rods are different. The regular FAL guide rod is in the bolt carrier. The PARA guide rod attaches to the Dustcover and has a metal latch, it cannot go into the regular Bolt Carrier assembly. You either fucked up or have your parts mixed up broseph.

It's possible, that your FAL is a FRANKENFAL, with Para dust cover, spring and guide rode, with a regular stock attached. Not the normal FAL where the guide rod and bolt carrier are connected and spring slides into the stock on recoil. You're making me really confused and worried senpai.

>but I’ll get the lower just in case.
Try it without the lower first and check fitment. Sell it to other anons when you can.

>Never had a chance to handle a PARA so wasn’t sure if the conversion was more involved.
It's E-Z, assuming your lower matches the stock. Other wise, it'll get complicated.

>>56928709
I read a bit more about this dude, and in the process I answered my own question. This Norwegian artist apparently worked in the US in 1933 and in 1939, living in Chicago and Hollywood. In 1933, he auditioned for Disney, and in 1939 they asked him to work for them, but he declined because he had family in Norway.
After the war, he was sentenced to 5 years in prison for treason, but was released after 2 years. Apparently one of his supporters was a resistance fighter who owned an advertising agency, who decided to help him out despite their very obvious differences during the war.
How wholesome.
He also made some psychedelic art in his later years.
Apparently he made about 300 propaganda posters during the war, where two thirds involved some kind of Aryan or viking imagery.

>>56853933
What I did was take an A4 sheet, fold them in half neatly, crease the fold, use a ruler to tear it in half and you essentially get two A5 sheets. Fold them in half, scrape glue across the surface evenly and take care to make sure no air bubbles are trapped. The small size leads to less bending and I'd use heavy books to pin them anyway. Repeat this while watching TV or youtube or whatever. You'll end up with a reasonable stack to work with. At this point you can use white glue to increase thickness, or superglue if you're feeling hardcore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56854169
Perhaps try using less glue because it seems the paper is being soaked through and thus takes too long to dry.
Alternatively:
- leave it drying in the open air for a minute, you should see it curl, flip it around to cause it to curl the opposite way and then after a minute put it under a weight
- before they start bending too much, glue them back to back so that the curling is neutralized
I admit that this requires experimentation and finesse to get your process down. Too much or too little glue have to be worked out as possible points of failure. I had an old gym membership card that is made of the same material as credit cards and it worked perfectly as a spreader.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dodecashotgun anon, back after half a year of absence. I've decided to more or less scrap the entire 3D printed fire control group and switch to the idea of electronic ignition for conventional centerfire cartridges. It is annoyingly cumbersome trying to hand fit a homemade system to function reliably 12 times over and I'm getting frustrated with not getting every barrel firing consistently every time.
I did a basic shit test with a bench supply and a primed case in my garage this afternoon. I just set the supply to 30V/10A, held ground on the case head and touched positive to the primer. The supply obviously current limited and reported ~7.5W power output. The primer detonated after approximately 2 seconds, or 15J dissipated energy. The primer actually blew out the back and damaged my alligator clip (pic related). I believe that the primer detonated from heating to its flash point. If energy is applied more quickly, a smaller area may heat up hotter without conducting heat to the rest of the case head, requiring less total energy.
ICs designed to charge photoflash capacitors to ~325V from a battery are widely available and inexpensive. At 325V, I would need a 300uF capacitor to store 15J of energy. This ends up being a realistic number; >300uF capacitors rated for >400V are widely available and relatively cheap. I'm going to see if I can dig up anything at work to test this further, or put in a digikey order if I can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56853904
Correct

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56854322
Yes, if you send electricity through something fast enough it will heat up more, and the smaller the thing you are trying to send it through, the more it will heat up.
Its directly related to the resistance of the material and the cross section area vs how much electricity you are trying to shove in.

This be something where you made your own primers, with an engineered strip of metal going through that would flare up and burn from your engineered current.

Alternatively, another potential design would be to create a deliberate plasma arc to ignite a primer, though I have no idea what the power requirements and speed for that is.

You can definitely make regular bullets work with electric ignition, but it will be a slower firing semiautomatic deal without a LOT of power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56855543
I understand what you are trying to say. In my mind, I had intended to accomplish this by having a sharper "firing pin" that makes electrical contact with the primer for the reason you described. At ~325V, an arc would form across a tenth of a millimeter gap, which is too small for me to expect to do deliberately. Some sort of mechanism to strike a spark like a welder is way more that I would want to take on.
What I was describing in my post was that I suspected that the 2s that it took for the primer to detonate with my 10A power supply was long enough for thermal conduction from the primer to the rest of the case head to have an effect. Doing some back of the napkin math, I think my guess was wrong. A shotgun primer weights ~0.250g. The specific heat of copper is 0.385 J/gC. If all ~15J was dissipated evenly in the primer itself, it would have raised in temperature by ~155C. The auto ignition temperature of primers is ~170-190C. The shells were at room temperature ~18C initially. This all adds up to the thermal conduction being negligible.
I'm looking into this specifically for a single shot breech loader, so charge time and battery life are not major concerns for me. A charge time of ~5 sec for a 300uF capacitor with a standard photoflash capacitor charger IC is completely acceptable to me. Better efficiency is desirable in order to have physically smaller capacitors, though.

I'm also a professional cutting tool engineer, so I give critics some slack. Not nearly as forgiving as a machine with 25-30hp.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56854322
Think that basing it off a stun gun would work better. The primer would have to me 3 parts though. A core, a middle and an outer layer. The core is metal, and has a pin sticking out into the cartridge, the middle is an isolating dividier and the out metal with another pin. Electricity is run through the inner to the outer and an arch is born. Might have to have the inside facing part of the primer be covered in something isolating as well except for the tips of the pins.
On the bolt you mirror the core, mid and outer. But in the middle you have a tiny button that gets compressed by the cartridge when the bolt lies against the cartridge so that the current can be turned on in the right position to avoid a short.
If you make the bolt out of a slightly heaver material you might be able to hollow out part of the back to fit the actual stun gun parts. Then there's how to hook it to the trigger properly but i don't know about that yet but shouldn't be impossible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56859015
>AR armorers wrench
good, but I find that I only really use the castle nut wrench after I moved to a freefloating handguard that has its own barrel nut wrench. Standalone tools are much easier to use
>Vise
good, make sure it's big enough and that's its secured properly, if you don't have one get a nice workbench too
>Punch set (w hard and soft punches)
Also consider roll pin punches and make sure to have a good plastic/rubber mallet and a roll of masking tape to protect anything nearby from getting marred.
Also related, get a center punch for staking castle nuts. You don't really have to buy a tool for staking the bolt carrier group since that should be done at the factory but you can if you want.
>Vibratite/VC/compound
Sounds good but every thread on an AR-15 that needs to stay is either torqued down tightly, torqued lightly enough that blue/purple loctite can handle it, or is staked outright
Optional, but get it if you want
>Glock sight tool
Sure
>basic cleaning kit/supplies
>bore snake
You don't need to get a full kit, just get the bore snake and buy whatever brushes/patches for the calibers you'll be shooting.
Speaking of cleaning, obtain a giant pile of cleaning rags. A rag to wipe oil and dirt onto is fucking useful and you'll be using it a lot. I have a giant pile of old socks with holes in them. Not great but it works.
>CLP
Cheaper options out there but sure.
>AR upper reaction rod
>AR buffer/receiver clamp (for holding buffer tube in place)
>lower receiver clamp
You could probably replace all this with a bev block, it holds both the lower and upper and it even engages with the locking lugs just like the reaction rod. You'll also get a ton of practice disassembling and putting the bolt carrier group back together which is also useful.
>Torque gauge/driver
Make sure it's calibrated. Also make sure to have a 1/2in breaker bar for going the other way.
>headspace go/nogo gauge
I'll defer to the more experienced but that sounds like a good idea.

>>56871200
It was safer (explosivity) and easier than the fulminate-based primers that preceded it, and it was safer (toxicity) and easier than the lead styphnate primers that replaced it -- we'd probably still be using it except for the whole corrosive salts thing.

Each component is safe individually, it becomes explosive after you mix it (wet) and let it dry. As with any priming compound, you want to use pure ingredients, and work carefully in small batches, but as these things go it's quite well-behaved.

Note that I have no experience with this sort of chemistry, I'm speaking from book knowledge, so please do your own research and don't blow yourself up.

>>56863435
On both a Glock and an AR, a Giggle Switch is compatible with an 80%, yes. You have to change the way you prepare and machine the AR platform to make it work. Polymer-80 ARs lack the "meat" to really take the modification safely: the FCG pins tend to egg out very quickly and can crack the walls of the receiver within a few hundred rounds of even semi-auto fire.
>>56871200
It's moderately poisonous and glass powder is NASTY shit, but you can otherwise safely mix the compound with acetone and work it wet with nonferrous tools on glass with no real worries. The acetone gets it into a thin, well-dissolved paste that's easily manipulate with a small brass spoon. or a brush. It helps that none of the sumbcomponents need to be in absolutely critical percentages *(my test cartridges still ignited with no additional hangfires or FTI when off by ~5%) and (unlike fulminates) you can safely make a few drams to load an evening's cases on the spot without having to brew, prep, and store several pounds of reeeeeeal twitchy primary high explosive in your shed. I do find the Primeall kits tend to make pretty soft primers, but shellac 'em in there and they'll hold up. Their Berdan and Boxer adapter kits are fucking nice for shooting old-school milsurps.
The problem is the potassium salts will deposit in the barrel and hunt every crack and crevice. You have to soak them out with hot water immediately after firing, flush the gun, then dry and oil it and repeat the wash a few days later,, or they will abruptly rot out your bore the instant the humidity creeps above 40%. It seems to be worse with "dirty" smokeless like 22s than the clean stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56888906
>>56892089
I've achieved the best results with sugar-nitrate string wrapped in ordinary cotton string as a protective layer. Pic rel.
My main issue with paper wrapping is that paper forms a non-permeable barrier. So you start to run into issues with confining the blast - which is a big no-no if you want a gradual deflagration. The last paper-wrapped fuzes I tested had inconsistent burns, they were difficult to light, and they behaved like literal firecrackers when I used my fast-burning powder composition.
By contrast, these were way better. The string did not confine the explosive gases, I could see the progression of the burn, and they were easy to light and transport.
I've found that this is a common theme with so-called "DIY" explosives. Most recipes are a good starting point, but there's a lot that you need to figure out yourself via careful testing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
According to Wikipedia the formula for calculating bolt thrust is simply the internal case head area times the max pressure. Going by that, case taper is irrelevant to bolt thrust. But this guy involves case taper in his blowback bolt weight calculation:
https://web.archive.org/web/20180206031407/orions-hammer.com/blowback/
So what am I missing here? And if a bottlenecked case really does create more bolt thrust, why?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56921212
Obturation. A straight walled cartridge will have more drag from the chamber, while a tapered or bottle necked cartdrige will have its drag vector slightly misaligned with the bolt's rails.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56921562
>A straight walled cartridge will have more drag from the chamber
Why? Many bottleneck rounds are "straight walled" up to the shoulder, so if chamber contact area is what counts the only difference in drag would come from those few millimeters of brass up front. Yet nothing I found online mentions this effect of case design on blowbacks, only the total amount of taper in the case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56852648
Someone should design a musket-lock that uses a modern jet-lighter as the ignition source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56921872
is it because a taper only has to move back a tiny amount and then it's not touching the walls at all?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56921872
Sliding drag force must be tangential to the interface. For the same obturation pressure and surface area, the total force on the chamber should be the same, but a tapered case will misalign that force with the bore resulting in less drag, and therefore slightly more bolt thrust.

There's another thing that might be going on that would be shared with necked cases, which would be the pressure causing the case to expand a little, which would cause the case to wedge itself out of a tapered chamber or out of the shoulder, and would contribute to additional bolt thrust if the bolt constrains this expansion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56925890
nitriding is a very difficult process to do.the ammonia process is gaseous ammonia, not ammonia dissolved in water. ammonia is a gas normally but when you buy a bottle of ammonia for cleaning, it's like 10% ammonia dissolved in water. like carbonated water, effectively. you can't really do this at home.
if you wanted to do nitriding, you'd do a salt bath one, like tennifer/melonite. you melt cyanide salts into a liquid at about 1000 degrees and soak the parts in it for a couple hours. you could probably build a kiln and do this if you wanted to.
nitriding is not a good option for a home gamer.

bluing is easy, parkerizing is not much more difficult. both are not great because you have to keep the part oiled. nickel plating is your next option. electroless is expensive, but electroplating with nickel is not difficult for simple parts. it's directional, so the part has to have a clear path of travel for the nickel ions from the electrode. so, it's difficult to do like the inside of a barrel, for example.
really though it's bluing, parkerizing, or electroplating. and that's it. or, painting with something.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56927139
>Though maybe by heating the part you can make the ammonia dissolved in water release ammonia gas so that it reacts with the part?
i really doubt it. the ammonia process is done in a furnace at around 1000 degrees F to crack the ammonia molecule into nitrogen and hydrogen. the furnace atmosphere has to be purged of oxygen to prevent explosions. if you could just heat up a steel part and dunk it in ammonia, they'd do it.

chrome is the best, but requires the use of hexavalent chromium, which is very bad for you, to put it politely. probably nickel plating is the easiest. nickel salts are also carcinogenic but much less of a problem compared to chromium.

>Aluminium oxide can be grown as a coating on aluminium by anodizing or by plasma electrolytic oxidation. Both the hardness and abrasion-resistant characteristics of the coating originate from the high strength of aluminium oxide, yet the porous coating layer produced with conventional direct current anodizing procedures is within a 60–70 Rockwell hardness C range[26] which is comparable only to hardened carbon steel alloys, but considerably inferior to the hardness of natural and synthetic corundum.
So basically, aluminium oxide is very high (good) but when coated on aluminum it's not in the same crystalline form as it is in a sapphire so it's not really as hard as one (bad).
Still, 60-70 is pretty good.
Unfortunately this will only work for aluminum, not for steel parts. Unless you can somehow manage to coat the steel part with an aluminum surface?

Hey anons, I am getting into the business of firearm manufacturing. I am currently processing for my ffl 7. My current business goal is to build/sell about 10 guns per quarter and then sell on gunbroker or privately. I am going to build uncommon guns using blueprints and already existing parts as templates to then build a complete gun. Just some background, i have 6 years exp as a cnc machinist, and 3 years exp as a toolmaker. I have a machine shop with everything I need to fabricate tooling, parts, and odds and ends. The only hiccup I have right now are the blueprints. If I cant find blueprints for certain guns I will just attempt to buy the particular gun or deactivated version, and categorize it as an investment expense. So far these are what I plan to build.
>winchester 1895 russian contract (I already have the blueprints and furniture templates)
>johnson rifle (cannot find any blueprints with measurements, might have to save up and buy one)
>webley mk4 (looking for blueprints, but I own one and might just have to bite the bullet and draw up blueprints)
>c96 mauser (i have blueprints)
>winchester model 12 takedown (no blueprints, but i own the gun)
>savage 1907 US trial version (managed to snag the blueprints for this)

Once my ffl clears I will pump out the 1895s.

Tldr the point of my post is to ask if anyone knows where I can find the blueprints I am missing? Other than going to a museum/university and making photocopies.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56932348
IED shaped charges that use a copper billet basically liquify the copper and squirt it at high velocity to slice through whatever is in front of it. Based upon that principle, I wonder what a mercury-filled space could be used for. It doesn't have to be all of the available space (because, weight issues, etc.), but any small amount, like 50 grams or so, might add significant penetration just ahead of the explosive to tear a rift through armor and allow the following explosion to be more effective. Perhaps much more effective.

I'm not a fan of the mercury hazmat contamination that would create. But for specialty cases, it might be worth it.

Other substances with very low melting points or are nearly liquid at similar temperatures, osmium perhaps, might suffice. Or, fill with fine pellets, like a #9 or #12 lead/tungsten/uranium shot, or even finer near-dust, and it might behave enough like a liquid to achieve a similar effect. Depleted uranium or copper powder suspended in plastic, for example, might behave almost exactly like a high-density liquid at such pressures.

I'd love to work on that research project with a fat $5 or $20 billion dollar research contract. I'm certain it would pay off. Applied flying IED technology.

Inferior for several reasons. Mostly. Higher melting point and much lower density for starters. If you want something hard, you want tungsten. Copper is much denser and can be forced to behave like a fluid. Etc.

If you wanted something really cheap above other compromises, then you could use something like pig iron or soft steel. That's why a research project would be advisable. Do you hold the BX25 like a vfg or a handstop (backwards pressure)? Because it seems to cause the feeding to slow down sometimes. The BX-15s are pretty reliable for me, and the 25s almost even more so but I don't use them as often. But still, clean the fuck out of them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56928679
Thanks anon, I appreciate someone else's input.
I'll admit that I did just buy a P322 a few days ago, but haven't had a chance to shoot it yet. I agree with most of what you said. My point of comparison is a Mark IV Target:
>The 25-round mags fix this issue, but are ugly af and have exposed rounds visible wtf close that shit off Sig
Thanks for letting me know that, wouldn't have noticed it from any of the pictures online. The main reason I bought the P322 is for the 20/25 round capacity. Guess I'll stick with the flush-fit 20 round mags.
>Trigger can still be pulled partly when the safety is on, and becomes mushy/weird. I'm pretty sure if you give the trigger a good yank with the safety on something will break.
Agreed, I think it's partially due to the plastic "trigger shoe" they used.
>Have to remove the thread adapter to remove the slide.
Yup, that's dumb. I think that the Mark IV will be a better gun to use with a suppressor just for this reason.
>action is a bit loud
The recoil spring bushing rubs along the machining/lathe tool marks on the barrel, making a bunch of noise. Would have been nice if they cleaned it up a bit.
Overall the Mark IV seems to be built better, but it's a big and heavy gun for only holding 10 rounds. The P322 brings higher capacity, smaller size, less weight, and a more modern design. Now I'm really interested to get the P322 on the range and see how it compares.

>>56907410
From an interview with Tim Cain, Leonard Boyarsky, and R. Scott Cambell on creating Fallout 1:

>In the Origins of Fallout, R. Scott Campbell noted that, "The nuclear Armageddon in the back-story was between the US and China. After shipping several people asked me why China and not the old standby, the Soviet Union. I made the choice when I remembered experiences with Oleg, a Moscow developer I worked with months before when I was assistant-producing a typing game. Once, in the middle of a phone conversation, I heard some muffled bangs, and the phone went quiet. When I asked him what the noise was, he replied, 'Oh, it was just the Russian mob firing their guns in the street.' I thought he was joking – he wasn't. After that, I had a really hard time believing that the once mighty USSR would be in a position to threaten the world any time soon. So I turned to the next major communist country that typifies 'the East': China.

WiC's scenario was fanciful even during the Cold War. It wasn't going to leave Europe by non-conventional means, full stop. Even the attempted Inchon by the Russians are Marseilles is laughable. What it did get right is that Germany devolved into a static meatgrinder much like Donbass within weeks.
What WiC's story IS though, is a compelling war drama set in the height of American culture, and for that I will always adore it.

Plus the gameplay system and multiplayer still have never been replicated (No, the 'Wargame's don't count, shut the fuck up.) and it's a real shame that it died off without much hope of returning.

posts.com:
modern MBTs have so many different variables to them that there is really nothing special about any one tank.

some have more front armor, others more side armor, most have different optics, different loading systems (autoloaders etc), some engines are better than others, maintentance is easier on tank A than it is on tank B, which in turn needs less fuel and so on...

the only two qualities that are pretty much identical for ANY western MBT:
1. their guns and the standardized projective types and calibers
2. they are not russian

#2 is a good quality for any tank to have
anything else is theorycrafting for neverserveds and warthunder players

>>56918881
Since anon doesn't answer I'm going to explain it. The difference between L/44 and L/55 is the length of the barrel. The number stands for the calibre x [number] so L/55 is 55 times the length of its calibre(6.6 meters, or 21.65 feet). While the L/44 is only 5.28 meters, or 17.32 feet long. A longer barrel means the round spends more time in the barrel, which increases its muzzle velocity, resulting in more kinetic energy.
