posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One claimed advantage of autoloaders is that they help make tanks smaller and lighter by eliminating the interior space needed for a human loader. Indeed, if you compare modern MBTs with an autoloader (K2, Leclerc, T-14, T-72 derivatives, T-80 derivatives, Type 10, Type 90) to those with a manual loader (Abrams, Arjun, C1 Ariete, Challenger 2, K1, Leo 2, Merkava), the former tend to be lighter than the latter. But, correlation does not imply causation. It should also be noted that an autoloader would still take up space in the tank and is probably heavier than the meatbag that it kicked out of the tank. And most autoloading tanks can’t just get rid of the turret armor because they put the gunner in the turret.
All things considered, do autoloaders really make the tank lighter?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56933240
>autoloaders really make the tank lighter
once the tank has been penned, yeah. the turret weighs a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56933240
It depends. Drop an autoloading turret onto a tank that wasn't designed around it and the answer is often not. You save weight by capitalising on the decreased volume you need to enclose with one fewer person. One less person means less volume, even if you move where the remaining people are. Less volume which means less surface area which means less armor for the same protection which means less weight.
Then again you can argue that an autoloaded tank won't be lighter because max weight is as much a product of logistical limitations as combat considerations and you've now just freed up weight to put in other systems, more armor, whatever.

posts.com:

Forces of the unknown have caused our world to merge/combine with a typical fantasy world. Old world governments have managed to hold on to major urban and suburban areas, but rural areas range from fragile peace to complete chaos. How are geopolitics affected, what wars may spring up in the wake of this development? How would the governments of this world seek to exploit those of the other world, or vice versa? What does /k/ do to adapt, survive, and profit in a world of elves, greenskins other fairytale fucks? What is the best AA for fighting dragons? posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
Newfag to fanksia, this is my first story. Please enjoy.
>My pack weighs heavily on my shoulders as I trudge through the picturesque landscape of a boreal forest.
>My hand finds its way to the tube secured by my shoulder, leading to the water bladder inside my pack. The tube lets out a small hiss of pressure as I undo the lock and take a sip
>The signature bitterness of iodine is present as I lap at water; greedily savoring the feeling of my parched mouth being once again moisturized.
>This was day two of my three-day expedition north from an isolated dwarfish mining outpost.
>My business is that of a merchant; though it feels more like that of a packhorse.
>In the times after /k/-day, the elvish inquisition had shown the lengths it was willing to go to in order to secure their hold on the knowledge of magic.
>Entire settlements of humans had been wiped out at the mere rumor of spellcasters.
>Military presence at that time had been limited. With the mass appearance of portals, the organization in our world had been pandemonium.
>The heavy restrictions on the study and use of magic and artifacts continues to this day.
>The need for a tradesman who not only deals in these artifacts and is willing to risk life and limb to transport them became apparent.
>I stop briefly in my tracks, hefting the pack higher on my shoulders and adjusting the straps and kidney pads
>I had never been one to squander an opportunity, especially one that would allow me to traverse the wilds and wonders of this new world.
>I put up my water tube and grasped my slung rifle, the steel rails warm from the grasp of my hands.
>A hearty weapon, from simpler times.
>A SOPMOD Block II clone, with EoTech RDS and magnifier.
>I had used these before in my military service, and thought so much of them that I bought one after my term had ended.
>The familiarity of the weapon brings comfort in these unfamiliar vistas.
1/?

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>In the brief silence of my pausing steps, I hear a faint whisper of sound
>I listen intently, drinking in the sounds of the forest as I had my water just moments ago
>Foreign, unfamiliar birdsong
>An uneven, loping rustle of brush reminiscent of squirrels
>And
>The faint babbling of a stream
>I let out a satisfied breath, and start towards it
>I stamp through grass and brush, pushing through some low hanging branches, fighting through as they insistently snag my pack
>Once over a small crest, there I see sand banks leading to a stream that flowed lazily over rocks, carrying pine needles off to some unknown destination.
> I slide the pack off my shoulders and set it leaning against a tree. Unfastening and flipping open the top, I take out my bladder and iodine tablets
>I sling my rifle around behind me, and approach the stream, undoing the top of my water source.
>I dip it into the stream, filling it with the cool water, and add the required iodine to ensure I die of causes other than dysentery.
>I walk back to my pack at the edge of the sand bank, and set the bladder next to it on the ground
>This may be a good a time as any to take a short break for some rations.
>Digging below the space that the bladder once occupied, I pull out thin strips of basilisk jerky
2/?

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>A hearty meat that fills the stomach and uplifts the hearty
>…or so I am told by the dwarfish shop keep whose nose, in hindsight, was rather large
>”Empties the wallet too, I suppose.” I mutter as I gnaw on the strips of dried flesh
>I had heard while I was at the outpost that the dwarfs would often encounter basilisks when mining at lower depths; accidentally breaking into their lairs
>This inevitably resulted in many dead dwarfs once a basilisk was loose in the mining tunnels, but the creatures were always brought down
>Afterwards they were transported to the surface along with the ore for processing; serving to feed the miners it didn’t manage to kill, devour, or spatter in chunks along the cave walls.
>I am ripped out of my musings by the smell of cigarette smoke drifting lazily on the breeze
>My heart leapt to my throat, and my mouth that had just been wet was again dry
>I cram the rest of the jerky into my mouth, grab my pack and bladder, and scan quickly for brush that could act as concealment
>Patches of tall grass grew along where the sandy embankment and the forest terrain met
>Not good enough for both me and the supplies
>I duck low and quickly approach the grass, setting my pack and bladder behind it
>Definitely not the best; but thankfully the gurgling of the stream conceals the soft thud of my pack hitting the ground
>I bring my rifle around to my front, and move slightly into the forest
>Still close enough to see where I had stashed my pack
>And where I had walked to the stream to fill up my bladder
>The cottonmouth feeling doubles in intensity
>There, clearly, on the sandy embankment are my boot prints leading to and from the stream

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Play Spellcross.

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>I swear under my breath
>The cigarette smell is stronger now, and my heightened sense make the taste almost palpable
>Over the white noise of the stream I begin to hear the harsh babble of a foreign tongue
>Gruff, almost animalistic; but with the timbre of a spoken language
>Prior experience informed me that these had to be goblins
>Keeping a deliberate finger on the lever, I slowly take my rifle off safe
>It disengages with a soft “tick”, and my finger traces the outside of the trigger guard
>Lower race or not, goblins had been slaughtering one another for years
>It was almost a certainty that such tracks would not escape their notice
>I hear a rustling on the other side of the embankment
>One… Two…
>They emerge from the brush, tramping across the tall grass, paying no mind to attempting to be cunning in their approach
>Three… Four…
>The descriptions of goblins that I had heard in fairy tails as a child were quite accurate to the real deal
>Five… Six…
>Green, leathery skin populated generously with bumps and warts, not unlike a toad in appearance
>Seven… The one with the cigarette.
>In the crisp air of the boreal forest, the smell of the cigarette was obvious; but overpowering even that was the stench of the goblins themselves
>The seventh appeared to be the last in the group
>The smell of goblin- that of stagnant water and fecal matter
>It had a tendency to dig into your nostrils and settle heavy on your tongue, where it stubbornly lingered
>A long, hooked nose like a Hebrew caricature hung over a drooling mouth that concealed thin, needle-like teeth
>The group sauntered out on to the embankment, taking little stock of their surroundings
>They all wore stained, torn rags for clothing, little better than loincloths
>Matching the condition of their clothing were the bags they carried on their backs, and the rusty rifles they carried that looked like they had been recovered from the bottom of lakes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

the bussy

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915057
>The seventh goblin did not have any semblance of a firearm, but carried a stick with various feathers and beads haphazardly attached with twine at one end
>The creatures dropped their packs on the sand, and they landed with dull thuds
>They stretched their arms above their heads, and muttered a few coarse words in their broke tongue to one another
>I released my grip on my handguard, and fished in my left pocket for ear plugs, never taking my eyes off the goblins, nor my finger away from the trigger
>I put in one with my left, replace my hand on the handguard, and put the other in as quickly as I can, feeling the pressure of not being able to fire while my right hand is busy
>The babbling of the stream, the wind rustling through the pines, and the goblin conversation becomes muted
>The muffled sound refines my adrenaline into a sharp point
>The three goblins who had been first in the clearing walk over to the running water
>They drop to their knees at the edge of the water, and setting aside their rusty rifles, plunge their heads in one by one to drink deeply
>Time seems to slow
>I can’t let this chance go
>I pause at the bottom of my breath, and train the red dot of my sight on center mass of a goblin who is starting to approach the stream to drink as well
>The trigger breaks crisply, the goblin crumples, a clod of dirt kicking up behind him
>The heads of all the goblins shoot up, with one of the ones that had been drinking choking and hacking on water
>Their movements are slow from my perspective
>My dot settles on the next goblin that hadn’t been to the river; another break, he falls
>The smoking goblin dives into the brush and scrambles behind a tree
>The last goblin who still hadn’t approached the river brings his rifle around to head where he aims it at my position in the brush
>Much to slow; I feel the recoil of my rifle, and watch the creature fall, clutching at its chest

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915100
>The goblins by the stream are still scrambling to orient themselves and trying to find their weapons
>Like a hammer sinking nails, my shots fall one, two, three into their torsos
>They fall, twitching and gurgling
>My sights flick up back to where I saw the last goblin disappear to
>The brush is still, and through the ear plugs my hearing is handicapped
>I slowly release the trigger, feeling the “click” of the mechanism reset
>I get to my feet, but remain crouched low
>I can feel my teeth buzzing from my heartbeat
>I begin to move from my position towards a tree to my left, glancing between the unmoving carcasses and where I had last seen the remaining goblin.
>The buzzing in my teeth I begin to hear in my ears
>And feel my torso
>What the Hell?
>The cigarette goblin steps out from behind a tree, his stick crackling with electrical energy and producing sound like the hum of a power station
>Screw moving tactically; I dive desperately behind the tree I had been walking towards
>A moment later, a bolt of energy impacts the tree, the impact sending me a flying a few feet back
>My ears are ringing, and I gasp for air, but can’t draw a breath
>I roll over on to my stomach, and push up on to my hands and knees
>My rifle dangles on its sling beneath me
>I look around bleary eyed, trying to orient myself
>I scramble in a bear crawl to behind the next tree I see, and rest my back up against it, gripping my rifle
>Again, I hear a humming to my 6 o’clock

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915110
>A glowing bolt impacts a tree ten feet to my left, exploding the trunk into splinters
>The bolt leaves a streak in my vision, and I can smell the burning of the pine sap
>Through the haze of adrenaline, a thought occurs to me
>If that didn’t hit me, then it doesn’t know where I am right now
>I take a deep breath to calm my nerves
>I can survive this.
>The impacted tree gave a few loud cracks, then a creaking noise filled the forest
>With a groan that seemed to come from a creature, the pine falls through the trees and landed with a “fwoosh”
>I take another breath
>I get down on my belly and begin to crawl and quietly as I can through the brush
>The pine needles dampen the sound of my movement, and the running stream provides masking noise
>I make it back to brush on the edge the embankment, and glance up and down the steam
>About thirty feet up stream I see the corpses of the fallen goblins, the sand around them now saturated in crimson
>The cigarette goblin is nowhere to be seen, although the odor still lingers in the air, mixing with burnt pine
>I try to slow my racing thoughts, and drag my mind out of the adrenaline rush
>It’s common for goblins to travel in packs, but usually large bands; less than 50 is uncommon
>This may have been a scouting party of some sort
>If I stay in my current position, it’s possible that the remaining goblin returns to a larger war band, alerting them to my presence in the forest
>But chasing after it when it has the ability to cast magic powerful enough to fell trees would be risking putting myself in harm’s way
>My finger absentmindedly traces the trigger guard
>The buzzing and electrical hum that I experienced were a few seconds before the bolt was actually cast
>If I could land a shot on him fast enough, I would be able to disable or kill him before he could finish the casting process

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915121
>Its current position was a mystery, although the still lingering smell of cigarette smoke informed me that it was still close by
>I glanced downstream again at the goblin corpses and the surrounding sand
>I settle deeper on to my belly and look through my flipped-out magnifier
>Although difficult to make out, I see that my tracks on this side of the stream are still by themselves
>So, it hadn’t crossed the stream to come after me
>My vision sweeps back over to the corpses of the goblins, looking for anything that may give me vital information
>Even now I see the blood continuing to soak into the sand
>The three that had been drinking and fell near the stream now bleed into the water, trickling red into the clear flow
>A rustle in the bushes
>And my nerves are instantly strained to breaking
>My sights train over to the moving foliage
>I hold my breath, waiting for it to appear
>A second passes…
>Two seconds…
>A small, furry creature resembling a vole the size of a rabbit emerges from the bushes
>It waddles unhurriedly towards the stream, presumably to get a drink
>I exhale, and feel slightly light-headed
>Then, a buzzing
>The small creature is vaporized on the embankment, sand blowing in all directions
>From downstream?
>I blink rapidly to try and clear the afterimage from my vision
>I see the goblin burst from the tree line on the same side of the stream as I am, staff crackling with energy, and his cigarette burnt down to the filter
>The bastard must have walking inside my tracks to cross the river
>I clamber to a kneeling position to have a better shot
>It’s head whips around to me, detecting my haphazard movement immediately
>We raise our weapons simultaneously
>I feel that horrible buzzing in my teeth as I lock eyes with the thing through my sights
>I jerk the trigger in my rush; my shot goes wide, and wings it in the right shoulder instead of center mass

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915143
>The goblin reels back, his staff also going wide
>The buzzing increases, and I again feel it in my chest
>The bolt flies narrowly to my left
>As it passes I feel the hairs on my arm stand up, and an intense heat
>The bolt impacts somewhere far behind me on the opposite side of the steam
>Even so, the blast wave causes me to stumble slightly
>Not enough, though
>I steady myself and again train my sights on the creature
>It screams gutturally at me, cigarette falling onto the ground
>Its staff raises, as if to cast again
>I squeeze the trigger, feel the clean break, and the goblin stumbles backwards from a center mass impact
>I fire again
>and again
>It falls, still gesticulating with its staff, and twitching
>Even as it lies still on it’s back, I put more rounds into it
>My bolt locks back
>I slowly lower my rifle while keeping my eyes on the body
>My legs are trembling, and my rifle that I had carried for so long suddenly feels too heavy to lift
>I drop to one knee, and take deep breaths
>My rifle is slung around to my side, and I take my ear plugs out
>The dampening of my hearing is lifted, and all at once I am basking in the ambience of the now quiet forest
>The stream seems to whisper sweet comforts to me, and I feel my heartrate decrease, and my heart descend from my mouth to its proper place in my chest

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915193
>A stinging sensation on the left side of my face makes itself apparent
>Must’ve caught some shrapnel when the tree exploded
>I get to my feet with a grunt, also now feeling an ache in my left leg
>Hopefully it’s nothing serious enough to delay me on my delivery route
>I trudge over to the corpse of the goblin
>The smell of goblin filth mixes with the stench of their foul blood
>A least 10 holes are dotted around the torso, arms, legs, and one in the neck
>I’m standing on it’s left side, the corpse between the river and I
>In its gnarled hand it still clutches the beaded and feathered stick
>Placing my heel on its arm, I yank the stick from its grasp
>It tingles in my hand, similar to licking a 9-volt battery
>Might be able to get a few copper pieces for something like this
>Doubtful it’ll work when it’s removed from the forest though
>I walk back down stream to where the rest of the goblin corpses laid on the other side
>Parting the tall grass, I grab my bladder and ruck from where I had concealed them
>The stick goes into the molle on my pack for the time being
>I move to a large pine tree, and take a seat, my back resting against the trunk
>Finally, the rest that I had intended to get
>It would be wise to move on quickly though. No doubt if anything nasty was in the area, it was curious what the gunshots and magic bolts had resulted in.
>The iodine-infused water tasted like a delicious reward after such a close call
>”Better see if they had anything worth taking,” I mumbled while getting to my feet with another groan
>The running water can’t be more than two inches deep, and several stones stick above the water, offering an improvised bridge across without the need to get your boots wet

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915206
>Stepping on to the other side, I take note of the sand that now appears dark brown, saturated with blood
>Glancing around at the weapons they held, I took stock. First, of the three by the river
>Two AK patterns, probably 47s
>A Gewehr 98 pattern rifle
>Curious, I pick up the 98 from the river
>Its wood is rotted, and the whole thing looks like it had been left out in rain several times. Rust spotted the metal from the bolt to the bayonet lugs
>I notice that the sights had been set at the furthest distance
>How strange
>Before I set it aside, an etching in the stock catches my eye
>Long faded, and blending into the rotting wood, a faint “ANA”
>A name? Or maybe an invocation of the Kube
>A rifle belonging to some long-forgotten novitiate of the old board
>Doubtful. Probably someone’s sweetheart.
>But just in case
>I plunge the barrel down into the sand
>From my belt, I draw a knife, and prick my fourth finger
>Blood drips on to the body of the rifle, running down the length of the tired wood, settling into the grain and pooling in the cracks and gouges
>Under my breath I mumble a prayer
>”Be you noble soldier or wandering vagabond, where ever you are, I hope you have witnessed this revenge, and this blood sates you. May you find peace.”
>A moment of silence passes
>Distance birdsong returns me to my senses
>Moving away from the three at the river, I inspect the packs that they had dropped on the sand

posts.name: Merchant Anon
posts.com:
>>56915215
>Rummaging through the first pack, I find foraged berries that were mostly crushed, coating the contents in sticky juices
>Loose bullets of various calibers, none of which I can use. Ammunition on this side is often difficult to come by, and is always a valuable item in bartering. Into the pockets they go.
>Some hard tack wrapped in large leaves. It’s probably edible, so into the cargo pockets it goes.
>Second pack, more of the same
>Berries, loose ammunition, hard tack, as well as a small knife with a flint blade and a wooden handle attached with twine
>An unopened box of Federal blue box .308. Very valuable.
>Third pack contained only various water skins and hard tack. Not going to risk consuming more goblin food than I have to.
>Rising to my feet, I inspect the other three goblins that had fallen nearer to the tree line
>Another AK, this one with synthetic furniture
>An AR, which upon closer inspection, was revealed to have a bent barrel
>At the very least the lower and bolt carrier group and be scavenged
>I pick up the rifle, disassemble it, and put the BCG into a pocket, and set aside the lower to retrieve later
>The final rifle, the one that a goblin had brought around to aim at me with, was a Remington 700 clone. I picked it up, and cycled the rounds out on to the ground
>More .308 to sell at the next town
>I should grab the magazines from the AKs, they’ll be able to sell for something.
>Nothing else of note was in any of the other packs, more of the same berries, ammunition, and a few loose magazines that were promptly pocketed
>I refill my bladder, drop a few iodine tablets in, grab everything of any value from the goblins, and prepare to leave the steam that had caused me so much trouble
>My leg and face were now causing quite a bit of pain
>I had intended to sell the acetaminophen at the next town, but if I wanted to make it there it was better if I used on myself now

posts.name: ELA
posts.com:
“Riders on the storm
Riders on the storm
Into this house, we're born
Into this world were thrown”
The radio droned on as flight crews made their final preparation to ride the lighting into Dhéǵhōm. Meanwhile you just sit back and mindlessly check your gear one last time while trying to get comfortable in the heavy humidity. You sit there watching the storm slowly approaching and there was an air of slight anxiety that always came when it got close to launch time. Looking over the swarth of passengers you cracked a shit eating grin “Lots of new bloods” you say to yourself.

You could tell who was new and who was experienced from what they were doing and how they composed themselves. The new guys were the ones talking and drinking amongst themselves, some of them even taking their drugs, anything to keep the nerves at bay. The ones that have experience are checking their gear, attempting to get some sleep before the flight, or shaking down the first timers for smart electronics that could get them and their chopper killed during the ride.

posts.name: ELA
posts.com:
>>56915590
You take your eyes off the chaos just in time to witness the arrival of the people who sponsored this flight. A Princeton University archeological expedition that partnered with the American Museum of Natural History and the MET to study and gather artifacts from various ruins in Dhéǵhōm. They must have given the expedition a blank check because the Sons have their entire fixed wing transport fleet here and a good portion of the helicopter fleet as well. A green flare went up signaling ten minutes until launch time and everybody scrambled to their aircraft. You get into your Huey just as the last C-130 took off and the DC-3s started rolling down the runway.

“Aren't they supposed to wait until the first aircraft is fully clear before sending out the second?” asks the college kid sitting next to you.

You turn to him and say “No, we got a small window to time to get into the storm to ride the lighting down into Dhéǵhōm. So they launch the next plane as soon as the previous one is airborne.”

“Makes sense.” the kid says.

“Say, How many people are on this expedition anyway?” You ask, surprised at the amount of equipment being used for this ride.

“You didn’t know? Every archeologist, anthropologist, professor, and student on the east coast that wanted in on this expedition joined up.” The kid exclaimed his New England accent finally coming through.

“That explains why the Sons pulled out enough aircraft to move a brigade.” You say as you attached your harness to the seat “You might want to do that as well, because once we ride the lighting it’s five minutes of straight freefall until we get to Dhéǵhōm” You yell over the noise of the huey’s blades as you take off into the storm.

posts.name: ELA

>>56915604
The storm bashed and bayed violently with lightning striking around you. You turn to the kid whose name you find out is Jeff. “Alright, which ruins is your expedition going to?” You question noting his unease.

His stammered reply of “Were headed to the Fuk Hor Palace then to the Bactrian cities and finishing off at Pueblos on the El Dorado Plateau.” confirmed your suspicions. That the people behind the planning of this expedition had no idea what they were doing.

“You're all going to die” You cackled out “The Bactrian cities are a warzone between the Pashtun tribes and Perun’s Chosen and the El Dorado Plateau is firm Injun territory, they shoot anybody that gets close unless they are invited and escorted in. Fuk Hor Palace is probably the only relatively safe place on that list and its booby trapped to shit”.

His rebuttal was muffled by the sound of thunder and a flash of lighting. “You see that over there” you say pointing to a bolt of lightning stringing one of the C-130s. “Relax” you say to the paniking kid who at this point was a hair away from hyperventilating at the sight of the vanishing aircraft “What do you think I meant when I said ride the lighting, we literally ride a lighting bolt down into Dhéǵhōm. What's next you're going to tell me you don’t know who the Fortunate Sons are?”.

The blank look on his face and the reply of “I don’t listen to rock'' told you everything you needed to know about the group of dipshits you're going to be babysitting. In a tone of barley repressed rage you say “How the fuck do you not know the name of the group that is currently flying you to another dimension”. Your attempted angry tirade was cut short by the copilot shouting “Thunder strike in three, two, one” the last thing you hear before the light takes you is AC-DC’s Thunderstruck playing on the radio as you enter into Dhéǵhōm.

The five minutes of straight free fall surrounded by an electric blue stops freaking you out after the first minute, or so you thought because Jeff is still screaming. You smack him one to shut him the fuck up and then turn to the rest of the guys in the chopper with us for some help and their amused looks tell me that this guy is my problem until we land.

“So why are you in one of the security choppers anyway?” You ask him.

“One of my classmates had a buddy from high school in this flight so I swapped seats so they could catch up.”

You blink at the display of ludicrous stupidity, readying a reply but you’re cut off by the huey lurching and the blinding light of the sun as your eyes readjust to the light. At that moment all the tension in the air drops as everybody celebrates another successful ride. Over the radio you hear “Welcome to Dhéǵhōm dipshits, it is currently a nice and sunny 87 degrees outside with humidity at 73 percent. To our civilian passengers I will kindly ask you to keep all arms and legs inside the aircraft until we reach our stopover at Kilgore Airfield. As for Fortunate Sons on this flight as well as independent raiders who rely on us for transport. Lock and load the chinks are attacking FOB Quaritch and we are the closest group that can respond. All security aircraft peel off and relieve FOB Quaritch, also heads up Rhuook and his band are there as well so watch your fire.”

Upon hearing this you all perk up as the stario’s in every chopper blasts Fortunate Son as you fly off into combat. You ready your Tommy Gun and look the kid in the eye and say “This is where the fun begins.”

They are in the eastern treeline. I repeat, avoid firing on the eastern treeline.”

“Copy that Chopper 4 we’ll avoid firing on the eastern treeline.” The cacophony of gunfire spewed from our chopper into the southern treeline led by Tyson and Johanes on the M60s. The steady clack of your Thompson was music to your ears as you fire into the treeline.

You charge forward towards the hill, your Tommy gun blasting as you charge. Your mad charge has surprised them allowing you to fell two positions with ease. You reload in cover and by the time you finish the Chinese on the hilltop have focused their fire on you. Pinning you to your cover.

>>56916204
Desperately in need of a drink you head off Babba Booey’s the best bar this side of Kubeloon. Clearing the rows of hangars and entering the chaotic sprawl of buildings that make up the settlement of Kilgore Station, you feel as if you are being followed, trying several times to catch a glimpse of your stalker but each time you are unsuccessful. Chalking it up to nerves you continue you march to Babba’s.

Outside of Babba Booey’s you find the palace to be in more anarchy than usual. Probably owing to both the presence of the research team and the rock apes. You see Bhouba, one of the rock apes, chugging a whole barrel of bourbon to a cheering crow. You give him a wave as you walk in to find Mac discussing something with Babba Booey. He leaves two crystal skulls and some clay tablets as payment before walking out.

As he walks past you he says “I’m serious about needing your help with the preparations my friend, as soon as my order is ready I want you to escort it to me or you're going to be at the end of the line for dinner.”

You shudder and let out a “yes sir” as he walks away.

“Hey Rabbit what can Babba Booey the Great and Powerful do for you today?” He greets you.

“Just a beer tonight, I gotta deliver Mac’s order to him and then help him with his grand feast or it's the back of the line for me.” You respond, finally starting to relax after a long day of bullshit.

“That is a fate I would wish upon any man” The djinn says while conjuring you up a bottle of Switchback.

“Still amazed you get that out here.” You reply, still wondering how a being from another dimension is able to import beer from Earth.

posts.name: ELA
posts.com:
>>56916396
“She is still looking for you, you know.” He says as you sip your beer.

“Still? I would have thought that she would have given up by now.” You ask.

“She is a persistent one, that she is. What did you do to get her after you anyway. Rabbit?” Babba questions while cleaning a glass.

“It's something out of a pulp story. I dumped some wild boars on her village and they believe it's a dowry. Next thing I know I’m held at spearpoint and married off to the chief's daughter.” You tell Babba.

He lets out a laugh and asks “and this is a bad thing because?”

Your only reply is “Dude, she’s fourteen years old, that is a major problem.”

“I am a multi-millenia old being, human ages stopped making sense to me a long time ago. Also Mac’s order is ready out back.” Babba replies.

“Thanks for the Switchback and the heads up.” You say as you pay him for your drink before heading out back.

Out back you find a halftrack laden with alcohol of many different types ready and waiting for you to hop on. You climb on the back and give the cab a good hit to tell the driver to start moving. The streets are quieter than normal and you soon see the reason why as you reach the hangar Mac converted into a smokehouse and chow hall. A large crowd had gathered around it and were being held back by armed guards as portions of the runway were also being turned into open air dining.

As you pull in, Mac approaches you and says “Ah Rabbit I knew you would come. I need your help making sure the rest of these numbskulls don’t fuck anything up while I’m finishing up the meat. We got mammoth, auroch, and buffalo on top of the usual beef, pork and chicken.” before heading off with a few bottles of the truck.

“You pulled out all the stops tonight.” You say to yourself as you get to work.

>"Next. I said next. You, Californian, over here."
Anon jerked his head up from his daydreaming, having become target locked on a oddly colored blob on the tile floor. Looking around he didn't see who was talking to him, so he stood, pointing to his chest.
>Sorry, who was that?
>"Over here, powder-bagger."
Anon leaned to the right and finally saw the rather short, angry older man who was snapping his fingers at him. The fellow was corn fed and beef bred judging by the looks of him, and Anon wasn't use to seeing such people back in San Diego.
>Right, sorry, here are my papers.
The older man plucked the state transfer papers from Anon's hands and quickly scanned them over, clicking his teeth as he did.
>"Here for work, are you?"
>Yes sir, I flew in only a couple of days ago.
>"Not surprising, no jobs over there in those heretical social hellholes."
Anon's lip twitched. He was still getting used to the absolute hatred the Midwestern Coalition had for California and the rest of the states that were within the Sanctuary States. The peace was still tentative in America, and the Union held in place, but it was only a sneeze away from going full Balkans.
>Well, yes, jobs are hard to find, but I managed to get into a software company here.
>"Holtenwasser I assume?"
>Yes sir.
>"Very well, he's a good man. Are you wanting to purchase your own firearm or are you wanting the stock hand outs?"
>P-Pardon me? Firearm?
>"It's standard here and part of our laws. You must be armed."
>Oh, im sorry, but I don't do guns, you see.
>"You do now, flower power."
Anon blanched. He never had much to do with guns, let alone the creatures that inhabited them. The ones that traveled with the police officers in California were dead-eyed looking things, if you could see their eyes past their blinders that is. His parents railed against them as well, calling them tools of the devil, and that only right-wing Nazi nutjobs wanted to own them anyway.

Anon muttered under his breath.

The older man looked up, cocking a brow.
>"What was that?"
>Nothing sir.
>"You can pick up your firearm on the way out, stop by the armory. Here is your work papers and your visa. After five months you can apply for a freedom residency."
Anon nodded, took his papers, then trudged out the side door to the armory. The air hit Anon's nose like a hammer, the pungent smell of oil, black powder, steel, and silica packets. The barred window was the only view port into the armory and behind it was a tired older woman currently reading through the newest edition of "Loaded Packages Weekly", a magazine known for its cool guns, and even hotter men.
>Um, hello?
The woman looked up, popping her chewing gum and brushing her lightly silvered hair away from her eyes.
>"You the powder-bagger?"
Anon scratched at his neck, avoiding her gaze.

She popped her gum again, then slapped down her magazine.

Anon watched the woman get down from her stool and sidle back towards the many racks and lockers within. Anon watched her go, then saw with curiosity that there were multiple bunks in the very back of the armory, round ten of them. Three of the bunks had an eclectic number of blankets on them, personalized to such a degree that he wondered if someone actually lived inside of there.

>>56927995
Anon jumped as the woman slapped down a solid plastic case, the three bold S. I. G. letters stamped into the case and filled with white paint.
>Ah... jeeze. Do I just... take it?
The woman grinned at Anon with a fair amount of snark, her canines flashing at him.
>"This ain't San Fransisco anymore girly boy, this is Oklahoma. Now take the pistol and git, I have reading to get back to."
Anon glowered at her, but picked up the case holding it carefully within his fingers. To him the case felt heavy, both in weight and in how ominous it felt. As he turned and made his way towards the door, he could barely hear another voice from within the armory.
>"Californian gone yet?"
>"Yeah he's goin'."
>"Good, can never trust those freaks."
Anon set his face at the words but didn't slow his stride, pushing past the door and out into the warm Spring sunshine. He had be warned that it would get rather sweaty in summer, but the job and quality of life would make up for that. Anon remembered back to just sitting inside his government sanctioned apartment, sweating through his shirt as he waited his turn for the A/C units to be powered on in the block.
Here all he had to do was flick a switch, and it did wonders for his moral. His little home was small, but he was able to pay for it thanks to the large advance from his job. The carpet was a warm gray, already furnished in plain, but comfortable furniture, and his new flatscreen was still humming with the news.
Further down in Texas, the Gunslinger Girl Gang was still on the run, having killed three peace officers in a robbery.

You fill your plate with as much meat as it can fit, auroch, mammoth, beef, chicken, gator, you name it you got it. And as you sit down to dig into your meal of meat you take a good look at the army gathered before you. You know tomorrow is going to be a mess as you dig in with gusto, the auroch being tougher than you expected but still very good. The chicken was cooked in what is on paper an unholy combination of honey mustard, buffalo sauce, and barbecue sauce, but tastes divine when put into practice. The rest of the barbecue however tastes strangely familiar, the bastard used your nonna’s sauce as a base for his barbeque sauce again. Not letting that get to you, you’ll save your vengeance against Mac later as you get up to grab some sides.

Through the chaos of the party you catch a glimpse of a headless figure that quickly disappears before you almost bump into The Kommando. He is chugging vodka from the filter hole in his gas mask, said filter being placed on the table.

He turns to you and says in his heavily muffled voice “Anno cheeki breeki?” while gesturing to the food.

“Uhhh yes?’ you hesitantly reply.

He gives off a celebratory gesture while saying “Ive danke” and then chugs another bottle of vodka.

Shrugging off that awkward and somewhat disturbing conversation you go get in line for more food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For me it was Day 57 (or whatever it was) of the 40 mile traffic jam. They had still been making some progress in the south but they had also taken big losses, so no one knew what was really going on. It was still assumed Kharkiv, Sumy, etc. were surrounded and eventually they would be forced to capitulate and Russia would envelop Kyiv from both sides. Instead, the second echelon in the north never came.

Suddenly, reports came in of Ukraine pushing to cut off the traffic jam on the west side of the Dnipro, and it seemed to dawn on everyone that Russia was well and truly fucked and if they didn't run away they were going to get surrounded and destroyed. That seems like the first point where I (and lots of other people) realized that "Hey, if Russian can't take Kyiv or interdict weapons, how the fuck are they going to do anything but a huge long, grinding campaign against a western supplied Ukraine. They were NOT prepared for this"

That's when I knew.

>>56905498
As soon as I heard about the Gostomel air assault force being flattened by Grad and Su-24 bombing runs on the night of the 2nd day. That instantly told me that Russian ballistic missile strikes and CAP have failed to destroy Ukie air force even with the element of surprise. Ukies had very few relatively old planes, their air defense wasn't great either (allegedly) and so it was immediately obvious that if their airforce survived Russian shock & awe and was actually running CAS at the tip of the frontline, then Russian attacks against other Ukie assents were a dismal, complete failure. Which in turn automatically meant that Russia had already lost the war of maneuver, right then and there. Sooner or later the losses from its checked thunder runs and open flanks will become so high it will have to switch to attritional warfare, just to have a chance to (at some point in the future) to defeat the conventional Ukie military. However, from the ferocious responce of the local Ukie population, even in the "pro-Russian" eastern regions it became immediately obvious that should Russia ever capture most of Ukraine and defeat its military, and some point in the future (back then I still considered that a likely possibility, though at enormous, ruinous attrition cost to russians), then its occupation forces would face the worst insurgency since Tito's Yugoslavia in WW2. So, the fate of the invasion was sealed then and there, on day 2 or 3 of the invasion. Then everyone saw shit like the 40-mile convoy running out of gas, Russian air defense network command centers being towed by gypsies and the question changed form whether Ukraine will exists by 2030 to whether Russia will.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56932908
Yeah they're fine. 7.62x39 is great out of short barrels. I have an 11.9" VZ that isn't too difficult to utilize building clearing tactics with. Keep in mind an AK will typically need a booster if cut to 12.5 (104 length) and the receiver itself is longer than a VZ. The VZ pistol lengths aren't cut down to the gas block, the gas system is shorter so they leave enough barrel on the end to get good enough powder burn past the gas port to reliably cycle without a booster. So you could run it with just a thread protector for the shortest possible package, or throw a birdcage type flash hider on and still be below AK104 length. Don't put a slant brake on a VZ, it messes up the recoil impulse since those are designed specifically to mitigate AK recoil impulse.

Either one you get is going to be good, but this is just my reasoning for why I went with a VZ as the top tier SBR. They're shorter overall and you're not limited to lame booster type muzzle devices. Ultimate indoor CQB 7.62x39 though would be an AK bullpup. A 16" barrel AKBP is shorter than my VZ with the stock out. You can get around corners easier, no stock needs to be unfolded, and you get the commonality of an AK. You'd have to chop your charging handle and use a gas tube handle if you want to shoot from the left shoulder. I've also considered a 12.5" AK as the bullpup build host but it's so short it's almost unsafe with how close your support hand is to the muzzle. I don't have an AKBP, I've only tested the dimensions with my AKs with their stocks folded.

This is my parts list for the bullpup build:
>cutting my Saiga to 104 length (I've been wanting to do this anyway)
>using said booooooster, maybe the extended version bc I'm afraid my hand could go in front of the muzzle due to how short it is
>building based off of this handguard or perhaps the SAG handguard
>figuring out how to use a metal wire as the transfer bar (seems easier than actually fabricating a transfer bar)
>figuring out how to make a new safety mechanism
>mounting optic to a sight base mount
>mounting backup irons to the mlok slots to use as tilted irons
>using a gas tube charging handle

If I'm happy with it I'll cut off the old charging handle and my AK will live the rest of its life as a transpup. I'll be expediting this process, will keep this thread and bullpup general posted. If you're interested in doing something similar I recommend you wait and see what problems I run into so you know what to expect and where to improve, or just buy a kit (CBRPS makes a good one & there's an airsoft copy of the Zenitco one that works on real AKs). If anyone can spot any flaws in my plan lmk. Seems solid enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56928810
i think it would become a game of who will course correct more efficiently.
for example, let's say two ships are in orbit, one ship launches a missile at the other, the missile burns for a while to get a very speedy rendezvouz(intercept) of the target. however, that target is still 140 kilometers away and has already detected the missile launch and is currently tracking it's trajectory.
the target craft burns laterally and changes it's inclination by a few degrees, because of the distance the deflection for the missile is massive and it will have to waste all the energy it commited in it's initial intercept and change course. now the target craft is of course limited in how many times it can do this, but it still has a LOT of delta-v and has the advantage of time and distance.
non-ballistic trajectories in space are REALLY inefficient and forcing a missile to take them could drain it's propellant very quickly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The killer app of starship is the raptor engines. They’re super cheap ($250,000 apiece), very efficient, and extremely powerful (510,000 lbs of thrust. For context a maximum weight c17 cargo plane is 580,000 lbs, which means with 2 engines it’d have better power to weight than an f16) also, for context the most powerful turbofan engine is ~100,000 lbf and costs $24m.
The extreme power and low cost makes a lot of crazy stuff possible and cheap.
One way to use these in the near term would be to make the first stage a raptor engine and propellant tanks, with a standard fighter jet on the front (maybe with a disposable heat shield over the front). These would be launched a few thousand miles from the combat area and would arrive via subortbital ballistic trajectory a few minutes later. The rocket and tank would be jettisoned and a fully armed and fueled fighter would descend at max speed, ready to kick ass.
Specialized military craft could be developed which use raptor engines. Probably the raptors would be paired with some combination of scramjet/ramjet/turbines to give power at different speeds for different missions (also because of the stoichiometry of burning methane, a large fraction of the reaction mass is oxygen so by using air breathing engines you can run the engines much longer)
For example, a superinterceptor might use a raptor to take off and get to high altitude and speed then switch on the ramjet to cruise at 5000 mph at 150,000 feet in 500 mile wide circles and pull 1.2g while launching missiles at anything that’s a threat. the superinterceptor could enforce no fly zones and shoot down any ballistic missiles in their boost phase.

>>56926228
I realize that these are donkey boilers, and thus little more than glorified hot water heaters with MAYBE 25# head, but Jesus!

In my career I had opportunity to root around in early1960s era steam engines of ships in the James River National Defense Reserve Fleet, which is one of three deep mothball sites for merchant ships, and NONE of those engine rooms had equipment that looked this bad.

Now upper decks was a different story…rust and layers of bird shit did a number on the topsides, but down below, it was just old…but not decrepit.

This looks like someone’s’ nightmare.

You can see the drum water level gauges, the vertical rectangular boxes with the vertical windows in them), THE second most important indicators after the steam pressure gauges, look like hammered shit.

So okay, these two boilers probably only make steam for the galley and the laundry, but still…

Like all major strategic concepts it is a combination of factors
>economic mass and structuring
>Production and defence economics
>organisational and doctrinal differences
>the presence (or absence) of democratic governance and civilian oversight of the military
>Institutional knowledge and inertia
>force generation and sustainment
>intelligence gathering, assessment and use
>alliances, shared values and the power of friendship
>technological and scientific development
>logistics and logistical planning
>geography and positioning
and many more besides. Despite what Chinese propaganda may tell you, the western powers and friends hold an edge in all of the fields mentioned above. In some fields that edge is greater than others, but it is present in all of them and that is why if war were to break out today the west would win
Also note that I have not mentioned any specific weapons systems or tactics, because these are not relevant to your question

Cannonically, Mobile suits are only about 60 tons and are roughly 18 meters tall. So imagine an M1 Abrams stretched out to a semi-trailer without any increase in weight. Honestly, if you put one in seawater it would probably float. This is somewhat explained by the gundam being made of some kind of super titanium and Zeon suits using crush armor(Mentioned offhand in Return of Johnny Riddhe).

This also sidesteps the Square-Cubed law as that law assumes that density remains the same.

AC7 was only disjointed because production was fucked up. They basically had to stop the whole project half way, nearly had it cancelled, and then picked everything up on a new engine. The Writing department basically had all these cutscene scripts that didn't agree with the gameplay scripts so they tossed all the cutscene scripts that made no fucking sense in context and tried to salvage the scripts that did. It's also why the cutscenes are so quiet and bland.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56918527
Titans are about 7-9 meters tall, which is on the high end of what I'd say is reasonable. At 7-ish meters you are basically the size of an IFV sitting on its butt, small enough to hide behind any 2-story building from a kneeling position or a 1-story building while prone. You can safely armor it against light autocannons without ground pressure being a problem. If you've got fusion (or super good batteries) and powerful artificial muscles (aka nanotubes), you got something that can do a mix of roles performed by IFVs, attack helicopters, and engineering vehicles, more resistant to missiles due to agility, and with a crew of 1. Tanks are still a hard counter in any terrain with long sightlines though.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56921288
I wish the series put more effort into showing ship classes and varieties.
Like those little cube fighter things Merkatz seems to use a lot for example.
Same with ground vehicles such as the respective tanks/ground vehicles of both sides.
But the alliance ships truly are something else. Less sleek than imperial ships but they have a utilitarian approach to them.
With imperial ships, they launch from ground ports and are built with landing on any planet in mind, be it on land or water, hence why they have their claws and perch themselves like a bird. They also have some aerodynamics in their outer design and have escalators and elevators for dispatching troops to invade planets, mostly in mind to quell insurrections.
The alliance ships have neat bridges as they have troops in them working and reading instruments while contacting other ships in the fleet. Imperial ships keep manpower on the bridge to a bare minimal. There is also a lack of pillars on alliance ships, meaning their captains and commanding officers have higher chance for surviving when a beam hits the ship. I could go on but the series has so many little details that are overlooked or not explained enough.

>>56934505
Here in South Africa we have loadshedding of electricity. So rolling scheduled outages for up to 8 hours a day. Many areas have water problems and there is a security threat from criminals. Add in inflation and most of the people that can afford it are becoming self-sufficient. I am fully off grid, armed to the teeth and have bug out plans in place to a place in the Kalahari desert if I can't get to Europe where I have a passport through ancestry. I practice with my firearms daily and have used them in protecting my loved ones and property several times. I'm a prepper out of necessity.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56933592
They built and tested nuclear thermal engines in the past, just never flew them. There are inherent risks to flying a nuclear reactor through the atmosphere, and launch vehicles were less reliable back then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56933684
On the flipside, they're also more economical on fuel which is the bigger reason the US wants one. If we have vehicles maneuvering a lot in cislunar space but limited refueling capabilities, we need to stretch that fuel as much as possible.
>>56933592
>why did it take them so long?
Lack of demand and insufficiently advanced material science. Old NERVA rockets had fallout in their exhaust because they couldn't shield the nuclear fuel without harming efficiency. Modern cladding for fuels can tolerate much broader temperature differences so they tolerate a gradient from liquid hydrogen on the outside to cherry red uranium on the inside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
PTR 32

On paper it seems amazing. Roller delayed 7.62x39. In reality it sucked balls and I have never seen a gun jam as often or in such unbelievable ways. Shell casings getting jammed sideways inside of the receiver and requiring the gun to be disassembled to remove was a repeat occurrence. It once double fed and slammed a round into the one that was already chambered so hard the bullet was pressed almost halfway down into the casing. The bolt face got jammed back so far that the charging handle could not interact with it, requiring another field strip.

It's a shame because it was really fun to shoot but the motherfucker had to go. It took an hour to clean it because every surface on the inside would get caked with carbon and then 60 rounds later look exactly the same.

My father in law bought it cause he thought it looked neat (which it does) but he ended up bleeding everywhere at the range cause he was on warfarin at the time.

I'm not a shrinking violet with recoil, but the AMT seems to be intentionally engineered to increase the trigger slap and transfer of shock to the shooters hand.

>You need to use hard cast heavy bullets through a 6-8" barrel to see tangible benefits from a .357
ignore the top chart that you see from bbti for 357 mag, it's simply not accurate. if you scroll down you can see real guns shooting real bullets, and 2" bbl revolvers are propelling weak ass factory 158 grain federal hydrashoks at about 1150 fps, that gives us about 460 ft lbs. this isn't a flattering loading of 357 either.
the most favorable real life example of 9mm being shot out of a gun on bbti is a 3" bbl shooting 115 gr +p @ 1200 fps, giving us 400 ft lbs of energy. we have a shorter barrel 357 with a less powerful loading having tangibly more energy than an ideal circumstance 9mm out of a longer barrel.

by the way, I wouldn't feel undergunned facing a large predator with a 9mm with the right loading, but I'd make mcfucking sure I was carrying a full size auto and not some meme pocket pistol. If I had to shove something small in my underwear and absolutely couldn't carry anything bigger I'd carry a snubbie in 357 mag and deal with the wrist torque later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56928246
.38/.357 is a rare example of a situation where you can legit save money by reloading. You'll only need one set of dies for both cartridges, and the .38 spl brass will basically last indefinitely if you load it at standard pressures. Loading .38 spl for a .357 mag gun is also one of the safest ways to start because you've got a lot of safety overhead as the gun is way overbuilt for .38 spl. If you just wanna dip your toe I'd get a Lee Hand Press (pic rel), a set of Lee .357/.38 dies, and a basic vibratory tumbler to clean your brass. If you don't already own a good set of calibers (which every man should) you'll need that too. The Lee dies will come with a volumetric powder scoop, which is good enough for getting started with .38 spl, but if you want to reload long term a Lee Perfect Powder Measure and a proper powder scale are both good upgrades. Get the carbide dies, then you won't need to lube your cases. If you have Scheels where you live, they sell these single cartridge reloading booklets that combine all the published data from every company for like $10. Scales are buy once, cry once. Nothing is more frustrating than a cheap scale that is inconsistent, inaccurate, and prone to wandering. Do not buy those Lee single caliber all in one reloading kits that require you to use a hammer. They work, but they are super frustrating and become useless if you decide to go deeper into reloading. The hand press isn't that much more expensive and I still use mine as a dedicated bullet puller even though I have more expensive bench-mounted presses. It's also a great SHTF press if you're into that sort of thing I guess.

I think it is interesting that Taurus has this weird sized "smaller than medium" frame size they use for some guns. They have their small j-frame size (models 85, 856, 605) and they have their medium k-frame size (82, 65, 66, 889, 669). But they also have a weird intermediate size that is between j-frame and k-frame. It is a noname size that they offer in some models like this 627. There is another one in this size, the 7 shot 617, and probably others. You can readily identify them by the position of the grip screw. This weird smaller-than-medium size screws from the bottom of the grip. I think some model of this weird size was the official Singapore police handgun for 30 years or something

I'm far from an expert on Halo lore. All head-canon. But that is what I assumed was being implied by some of the more absurd small arms.

According to Halo lore the M6 series had been in use since the early 25th century (no mention of if they were always chambered in .50 cal) and became the standard UNSC sidearm during the Human-Covenant war. There were “up-sized” variants made during the human-covenant war specifically for Spartans, but the non-Spartan versions were still cambered in .50cal. In the lore the guns are considered heavy and despite being the “official” UNSC sidearm its weight is said to “limit” it distribution among UNSC servicemen.

I don’t think it’s ever been explicitly stated, but the idea that the UNSC just took a bunch of existing and rare high-caliber guns and started mass producing them for standard issue during the Human-Covenant war makes sense. Who cares if an 8 gauge shotgun that will break the back of every female navigations officer who uses it is made the standard shotgun of the UNSC, it’s meant for a roided and armored male marine/ODST who has the life expectancy of a fly and who has to fight 7 foot tall, 500 pound, shielded monsters as a living. Same goes for a standardized .50 cal sidearm, what’s the point of issuing a lighter caliber when the only people who are inacaple of using the heavier caliber have no use for a sidearm, or any weapon in general?
